number of helpful: 414 of 430 people (96%) found this review helpful33 people found this review funny
content:
ber 17, 2015
												Many moons ago in 2003 I stumbled upon a trailer for a game called S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Oblivion Lost 


YouTube™ Video: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Oblivion Lost trailer 2003 

			Views: 83,037		

			"Oblivion Lost" trailer 2003 Music : Dmitry "Kaos" Kuzmenko - Invisible Dangers Part﻿ II		

 Needless to say after watching that I quickly became obsessed with this game. Searching high and low for every bit of info I could get my eyes on, The GSC forums became my 2nd home while I awaited its arrival. I remember at the time I was playing Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, With it I fell in love with non-linear open world 1st/3rd person games with RPG elements and how much I could get immersed in virtual worlds. I am all for fantasy settings don't get me wrong, but there is nothing more terrifying than reality. (With a spin of fiction of course, alternate reality if you will) The abandoned urban/industrial locations in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. were more my cup of tea. That in itself made me very excited to play it. I couldn't wait to get lost in its world. While I waited though I researched about the Nuclear disaster at Chernobyl in April 1986, it was mixed emotions for me. I was sad/amazed/intrigued. Sad for all of those people who lost their lives because of this. Nothing but respect for the liquidators and anyone involved in the initial cleanup. Those people are heroes and deserve nothing less. Amazed that this game had some real history in its background story. Even if it is incredibly embellished (mutants, anomalies, artifacts etc etc.), you have to admit it makes for an interesting premise to a story. Finally, Intrigued on what these game developers had in store for the players to experience, without making a mockery of those who had lost their lives in this tragedy. The game also borrows elements from "Roadside Picnic" by Boris and Arkady Strugatsky and the 1979  Andrei Tarkovsky film "Stalker". If you haven't heard or checked them out yet, they are most definitely worth it. Masterpieces in their own right.Well turns out it was a long wait lol, game finally arrived in March 2007. It was no longer Oblivion Lost, it was now called Shadow of Chernobyl. Which was a welcomed change imo, what was not a welcomed change was the amount of content/features that were removed from the game. Vehicles, locations/maps made smaller and simpler, monsters/mutants, superior lighting from old alpha builds among many other things had been removed it was rather disappointing to say the least. The survival aspect of the game took a huge hit, leaving many in the community confused as to what happened during development. GSC Game World regardless of all the missing features still delivered a good game and it was well received by critics as well. The game at release had performance issues and bugs that required some patching. Once that happened it was clear that S.T.A.L.K.E.R. - Shadow of Chernobyl was a game ahead of its time. In a league all its own and a true gem in the PC gaming world. The atmosphere takes front row seat in this game it is almost like another character in the game. Such believable atmosphere it is downright amazing, it keeps you on the edge of your chair as you play. Pros:- Incredible atmosphere!- Impressive use of lighting and shadows, - Cloud shadows that shift as day/night cycles progress. - None stylized (photo based) textures (adds to the realism), Replicating the rust and decay feel.- Great cut-scenes that hold up even by today's standards. - Plenty of side quests - Exploring is encouraged to find secret stashes scattered throughout the world to find loot, weapons, ammo, suits and artifacts. Artifacts can be placed on your belt to grant the player abilities like resistance to radiation, increase weight limit etc. Some interesting combinations that can be made with the multitude of artifacts available in the game. - The games AI can be quite challenging because they adapt/react/flank/take cover depending on your approach. This adds to the games replayability immensely, if its one thing I have learned playing this game is that when it comes to killing the AI is that no playthrough is ever the same. Never. They are very unpredictable lets put it that way.- Trading system with merchants and other friendly AI characters- "The Zone" is alive even when you are not in the same vicinity, AI will be fighting mutants and/or other factions (Bandits, Duty, Freedom, Loners, Military, Mercs, Ecologists & Monolith) All fight among themselves.Besides all the bells and whistles the story is incredibly engaging and keeps you interested throughout. Without too many spoilers (I am sure most people reading this have already played this but still) You play as "Marked One" an amnesiac trying to retrace his steps, he is then set on a mission to the heart of "The Zone" (term used to refer to the 30 kilometer Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, established after the accident.) to find a target and their whereabouts. Game also has multiple endings depending on the choices made by the player, 7 in total.Cons:- Lots of "fetch" side quests (Surprise? lol)- AI that can sometimes see you from "miles" away (vanilla)- Some quest giving characters can die. (vanilla)Just a heads up. Nothing game breaking but worth noting. Just like all games, it is not perfect. :)-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The mod scene for S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games is very much alive.When your done with vanilla (though not necessary, I would recommend the community fixes of ZRP goes well in a first playthrough to have the best bug-free experience with the game). Shadow of Chernobyl has some amazing mods worth playing, especially if you are looking for new storyline or another playthrough with better visuals, more weapons, new side quests, improved enemy AI, realistic weapon damage & accuracy etc. Some I can recommend are:- ZRP (Zone Reclamation Project) (community fixes keeps vanilla intact) ZRP[www.metacognix.com]- Priboi Story- L.U.R.K.- OGSE (Old Good Stalker Evolution)- AMK v1.4 - Secret Trails 2- ABC Inferno (if you are a masochist)- Narodnaya Solyanka variants (my favorite Narodnaya Soljanka DMX 1.3.2 dkz02)- Autumn Aurora- STALKER Soup- Oblivion Lost- AMK: Autumn Edition- Lost Alpha (standalone)Some of these mods add in the cut content (mutants, weapons, vehicles etc.) The list goes on really, just my humble recommendations on the ones I have tried. Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat are awesome games as well, worth checking out at least once. They also have great mods which I will not mention in this review. But I will say that there is something about Shadow of Chernobyl's allure and atmosphere that didn't carry over as well to the other two games. Out of all three games, Shadow of Chernobyl is by far still my favorite.I don't claim to know everything about these games, because honestly I don't. I still discover new things about them every time I play them. They are gifts that just keep on giving. Thank goodness for Eastern European  game developers!5 stars ( ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ) out of 5

content:
r 15, 2014
												Get the community patch which upgrades graphics, enables quicker keys to save, breakable lights fixtures and more! Takes the game from good to great! STALKER is my favorite gaming style! (I got the file patch from gamefront. Its 703.1MB and an exe.http://www.gamefront.com/files/16359911/STALKER_Complete_2009_# )Sneak around and attempt to take out any force with stealth attacks. The more silent you are, the more deadly you become. When you kill an enemy, pick their body up and hide it. Enemies see only whats in their vision, and while an enemy is in-sight they appear on your mini-map. If you don't crouch, they will hear you even easier! Turn on night vision and pull out your silenced weapon to become the ultimate STALKER! (still challenging!)Each NPC has a unique name, and they will remember if they like you. They can die from enemies too, though. The killed NPCs are replaced with half as many fresh new NPCs, most of the time, which helps the game still feel alive, and progresses. If you shoot your friend once, they will forgive you. If you shoot them twice, then its war...There are different groups/factions. Military, Bandits, Loners, Duty, Freedom, etc. Everything is at war. If you pis-off the Military, they will attack your base. If you don't ball-up, they will all die. Game changing! Although, you can save anytime you want. Which makes winning a serious battle, actually possible. Making you the most badass in the zone! Although, no one truly knows how cool you are, due to saves! ;D  (I wish there was a video replay, where it shows you how [through saving] your character is elite.)Mutated animals run around constantly. Sometimes you can take a souvenier from them. The types of mutated creatures become really sneaky and different than you can imagine. They will solo attack armed soldier squads too. Sometimes wiping them out. You get no rewards for helping NPC communities survive, but it is rewarding to know you just saved a friendly base.Better equipment comes much faster from helping NPCs with a task. But you will probably gain access to much of the same guns much later on, from fallen enemies, except armor never drops from enemies. Bullets fall with gravity. You can watch a bullet fall towards a distant target. If you choose to use a sniper weapon, you will have to adjust your manual aim to compensate for this new thing called gravity. Also, the distance between you and your target feels real!What else... there are... artifacts, which give bonuses. They are supposed to be found in anomalies, which are dangerous ghost like traps. If you hear your radiation meter going off, throw a metal bolt by pressing 6, to see if you are about to get zapped by stepping on a trap. Also, if you hear radiation, you are probably getting pummeled with radiation poisoning. Might want to step back. Suit up to get less exposure! (This seems bigger in the game Pripyat.)Lastly, the atmosphere is really in depth. Everyone speaks with a Russian accent, and when the wind blows the bushes wave. Day/Night cycles and eating let you feel like you are really camping in the zone. Its cold and a loner's friend.

content:
er 25, 2013
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R can be best described as "That Russian game" because it just is every Russian fantasy period. Running through Chernobyl killing mutants. I mean there's more to it than that but everything, from the look to the amount of Kalashnikov porn lives and breathes Russian and to a greater extent Ukrainian culture.The premise of SoC is that you are a S.T.A.L.K.E.R. A treasure seeker and one day you awake with amnesia with a single objective reading in your PDA. "Kill STRELOK". With no further purpose in mind you set off north to the power plant where mutants and other stalkers reside. What I love about the plot is it has this inherant mystery to it. You gradually uncover more clues about Strelok and his group, and about the Zone of Exclusion as a whole. Compared to the two other S.T.A.L.K.E.R games, this one sets the stage as both a horror game and as a mystery game.Adding to that SoC has very challenging complex gameplay. The AI is very good and GSC intended the firefights to feel similar to multiplayer matches in games like Counter Strike. The AI waits for you, it ambushes you and ramboing in only seeks to get you killed. You have to be smart about your engagements.One thing to note about this game and the other two is that there are mods that fix most of the bugs and improve the overall gameplay. The two I recommend are STALKER Complete 2009 and LURK.


You never thought STALKER could look like this could you? 
A Screenshot of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl
By: ✨Beyond Heretic✨

												The BEST GAME EVER MADE!!!!  Sure it has its fair share of glitches but if you look past them you are in for the ride of your life!!!!Pros-Very Challenging-Tons of very good mods-The most atmospheric game ever-Actually creepy as hell at times-Better ai then even FEAR-Fire fights are really epic espcially when you fight the military and monolith-Long main quest; takes about 10-15 hours to complete-The locations in this game are based on real life Chernobyl, which is very haunting especially when you are alone-Really cool monster designs-Craploads of weapons -Alot of side quests-Music is fantastic-Pretty big open world; although it is segmented-Multiplayer is actually fun, although don't get this game for it's multiplayer as its mainly dead except for a few Russian Servers-The many different factions are all very cool, my favorite is Duty-Artifact hunting is fun-Exoskeleton is the coolest power armor ever-The wildlife is better than Far Cry 3's as they hunt each other and even eat dead Stalkers-Ok storyline not great but not badCons-Extremely buggy; I suggest you download Stalker Complete 2009 for your first play through as the vanilla game is even buggier than Bethesda games-Steam decided to update the game to 1.0006 patch which is a very terrible patch as it crashes everytime you loot a body; I suggest rolling back the game to 1.0005 as its more stable and more mods are compatible for it.  Just look up how to do it on the steam forums its there somewhere-Some characters tend to repeat lines over and over again when you are standing near them; there is a mod to fix this so I suggest you find it on Mod Db

												It's not a horror game, exactly, but it has one of the bleakest atmospheres I've ever encountered. The sandbox elements enhance the feeling of being trapped in a nightmarish world ravaged by nuclear disaster.  Of course, there is more to the story than that, but anyone who is fascinated by the horrors of the Chernobyl disaster will be interested in this game. content:
25, 2014
												I was recently introduced to the S.T.AL.K.E.R. universe through Shadow of Chernobyl. I was won over by this, it has so much going for it. A FPS sandbox game set in the Zone, a secret scientific facility with mysterious environmental anomalies in the ruins of Chernobyl. You are a Stalker, one of the many rogues who make a living by scavenging the ruins and seeking valuable rocks. The environment is challenging, the array of weapons and other items is huge, great missions, great gameplay (stealth, economy, range and style of movement), plenty of mystery. I like that the gameplay continues while you rummage through your inventory. I really appreciated being immersed in a cultural environment that was not the usual Hollywood inspired rubbish - in this world you are a person with no history, trying to figure out your past against a Ukrainian-flavoured backdrop amongst hardened and macho men. This has a lot of blokey appeal. This is one of the best dilapo porn games ever, picturesque and epic. Whenever I play a game that is based on a real-world location, I'm usually disappointed, but the Chernobyl Power Station map was one of the most enjoyable I have ever encountered, and not just for its epic representation of the location. This game is as close to perfection as a game can get.I highly endorse this and Call of Pripyat - weeks of fun, and I can't wait to check out Clear Skies.

												I'm walking through this area called "The Garbage" or something similar. Hear a cry for help on my PDA, some STALKERS are being pinned down by some bandits. Decide to go in and help. Clear bandits and meet with leader. He thanks me and says he'll take me to this underground tunnel where they heard there was a weapons stash, but couldn't get to. Okay, sure, I could use the guns.Climb down manhole. It's quite dark. Crouching as to not be loud. Come to a doorway and peak around. See 5 or so guys. One of them must have seen me, they start shooting at me. Throw grenade and take potshots with pistol to save precious submachine gun ammo. Kill bandits after a few minutes. Loot their bodies. Take a staircase nearby. Keep hearing this huge "whooooooshhh" sound. Go to check it out. Lightning is sweeping down the corridor, not an anomoly I'd want to be in. Take a different route. Sneak down this spiral staircase. Walk around acid anomolies. Come to this broiler room. Walk on this edge by a wall. Super dark down here, have my flashlight on but don't want to be seen. Take out my binoculars to see far end of the room. Binoculars will automatically highlight a target if there is something in your field of view...something gets highlighted. I'm not down here alone. Start to creep forward, hear really heaving breathing. Creep forward again, hear footsteps. Scoot back against the wall. Wait for a minute. Equip best gun and decide to go for it. Start creeping forward. Hear running behind me. All I can see are these glowing orange eyes, and the outline of something invisable. Panic shoot, forgot gun is in single burst mode. Panic clicking. Thing runs away, so do I, back into my corner. Heal up and reload. Step out again. Crazy ♥♥♥ thing comes running back, load about 40 bullets into it til it drops. Looks like Cthulhu.Hear shouting at other end of hall. More gun fire. Sound like another creature is fighting some more people. They chase creature my way. I'm trapped in corner. ESC. QUIT TO WINDOWS. I played for about 15 minutes.

content:
er 25, 2013
												A Stalker is someone who ventures into the ecological disaster zone created by the fictional second explosion of the Chenobryl Nuclear Power Plant to recover artifacts that defy the laws of physics. I won't go into further details of the game, as I the mysteriousness of The Zone, and how to survive there are the most endearing features of the game.It took me a long, long time to fall in love with S.T.A.L.K.E.R. I first booted this game up on release day, and my good 'ol Athlon64X2 choked on it. Performance won't be a problem in this day and age, but the X-ray engine's poor optimization was killer back in '07, and the fact that the patches would erase your save game only added insult to injury (again, this won't affect the gamers of today). After I had finally tweaked the game into a playable state, I found an intriguing title with a fantastic premise, and a living, breathing world overflowing with atmosphere. However, exploring The Zone wasn't the beautiful experience that it should have been. The place was crawling with bugs, glitches and anomalies (and not just kind you are supposed to be exploring there!) The shooting physics were far from consistent, the translations were poor, and the game would still crawl along at a snail's pace. There is still much to love about the game, but playing through on vanilla left me feeling that the title just didn't live up to all that it could have been.That all changed with I discovered the heavy modding scene for the series. I recommend reading up on the various fan overhauls for Stalker, and installing one before you even first step foot in The Zone. There are many to choose from, such as Complete 2009, Misery, or my personal favorite, Lurk. After playing through the game with fan enhancements, I found myself beyond taken by this title's bleak wonders. I would go as far as saying that Stalker with the Lurk mod is my favorite first person shooter experience of all time. I found myself so infatuated by the Zone and her mysteries, that I read  and enjoyed the book ('Roadside Picnic,' Arkady and Boris Strugatsky, 1971) and  watched and adored the film ('Stalker', by Andrei Tarkovsky, 1979). I also researched the fascinating tragedy of the real life Chernobyl disaster of 1986.In conclusion, if you are a patient gamer who fancies a real challenge and getting lost in a bleak world in a devastated Ukrane, I simply can't recommend a modded version of S.T.A.L.K.E.R enough.Get out of here, Stalker. 100 Rads out of Ten

Gameplay+ Good simple HUD.+ A shop trading system.+ Inventory system and looting.+ Controls are fully alright and work fine.+ Different types of mutants a great addition.+ Scary at times, keeps the direction perfect.+ Requires skills and tactics as well taking cover.+ Weapons are solid and actually similar to real guns.+ No level system bs. It makes the immersion more real.+ Mod support. Many mods to make it even more greater.+ One of the most atmospheric games, it feels like you are there.+ Guns have conditions the more worse quality the more the jamming.+ Artifacts can be used to enchance some statistics or sold for money.+ Ahh just lay down in the campfire eat sausages and listen to guitar with fellow stalkers.+ You can still occiasnly find multiplayer matche's due to the fact that people can host there own.- Few side quests.- Not true open-world.- Loading times can get long.- No weapon or armor upgrading.- Some guns really can use many improvements.- No engaging tutorial, only text pretty barebone's.- No fast traveling, requiring you to walk back many times.- Bugs and many of them luckily there are mods that fix emm.- Many artifacts are just scrambled around and require no real work to get.Graphics+ Overall graphics are pretty fine and good.+ Lighting effects are amazing just a well done job- Textures can use many improvements.A.i （Artificial intelligence )+ Every mutant behaves in different ways thus adding variation.+ Just amazing, they take cover,they try to flank you and have a mind.+ The world A.i is always on i mean suppose you are in other area if you go back to other ones different things can happen like for say a loner camp and now a group of bloodsuckers attacked it.- Buggy,buggy A.i while what it does is amazing but many times just buggs ethier they will get stucked at a certain position, not respond or come and many more.Story+ Immersion and real immersion.+ A unique while a bit super natural story.+ Great voice acting matches every character.+ A believable world and based on an actual location.+ Many turning points and just keeps wanting you to play.- While can be alot confusing for starters.Design+ Overall environment really just great.+ Well designed world and actually does seem believable.+ Overall presentation is great already gives you a feeling of pure bitterness.- Many generic and poor design decisions.Sounds and OST+ Environmental sounds are just amazing.+ Guns,walking and all that have great sounds+ Great guitar-tracks keeps you listening even more.+ Menu music and all in between may seem odd but fully matching.- Dynamic music option. It's really not that great mostly just really lame.ConclusionA hella great game but more of a experience. Well directed,good voice acting,solid guns,many realistic elements, tactical, good A.i,Different mutants while some poor design decisions and many bugs and missing features.But if you can handle its issues a definitely worth getting game and something not so easily forgettable.===================================================================Click me and follow us as Curator

content:
r 18, 2014
												Yes the game is plagued by bugs, but gaze over them (or just install a simple mod fix) and what you’ll find is an FPS with RPG and horror elements that evokes feelings that you’ve possibly never experienced before. It perfectly captures the overwhelming mood of a decrepit world without getting repetitive or monotonous.It captivates you, inundates you with a constant wave of ambience and atmosphere, creating an illusion of desolation. The realistic gameplay and sound effects coupled with the brilliant soundtrack and periodic spine tingling bellows from mutated monster(lings) in the distance helps forge this. So despite being armed to the teeth with lead, gunpowder, rations and a generous light source it does what most (survival) horror games fail to do. It’s a preview of emptiness and loneliness. It makes you hesitate. Permit yourself temporary freedom and succumb to misery and mystery in the dense expanse known as The Zone. Recommended mods: -Autumn Aurora 2: Necessary tweaks and amplifications of what makes the game great while also keeping your experience as vanilla as possible.-Zone Reclamation Project: All your technical issues fixed with one simple mod. Additional recommendations:-Russian dictionary..

y 23, 2015
NOTE: As I am reviewing the original product, and not various third-party mods, this review is based on a vanilla playthrough. Please keep that in mind, thank you.+ Functional, user-friendly navigation and quest-mapping device+ Artifacts add slight RPG-like stat combinations+ Vast, detailed environments+ Very, very strong sense of atmosphere pervading throughout+ Boasts a large and active modding community (many mods do well to address some of the game's various pitfalls)+ Equipment and weight limitations do much to force the optimization of one's gear, and make one choose what to discard and what to keep; this leaves the player feeling both challenged and rewarded as they acclimate to the concept+ Ambient sounds are absolutely fantastic, and keep the player consistently unsettled+ Weapon degredation adds to the challenge, and makes one keep an eye on their equipment+ Manner of interaction with various game-world NPCs is largely determined by the player's actions throughout the adventure+ The game's world and atmosphere compliments an intriguing plot; the story, itself, rewards inquisitiveness+ Moderate variation in firearms+ Absolute plethora of side-missions- No fast-travel; this likely will not bother the realists out there, but I felt that there could have been a comfortable middle-ground implemented that would have kept everyone happy- Lots and lots of bugs, some of which are quite problematic (again, most of these can be remedied via the modding community)- Largely flat and uninspired voice-acting- Malleable NPC relationships notwithstanding, the story is fairly (although not completely) linear- No autosave function (except when entering new areas, but the environments are mostly sprawling areas, making this insufficient); massively frustrating when you die 45 minutes into a new area and forget to manually save, forcing you to take significant steps back in progress (although I believe there is a mod available to remedy this)LockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

r 25, 2016
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is one of those special games that punches way above its weight class. It seeks to be an open-world, open-ended FPS/RPG with fluid relations between characters, emergent behavior in the wilds, and a compelling story and setting underpinning the whole thing. Those are lofty goals for any game, much less one from unproven developers back in 2007. What's shocking, then, is just how much it gets right even by modern standards.In the world of S.T.A.L.K.E.R., the Chernobyl disaster spiraled outward to create the Zone, a harsh land ruled by mutated creatures, spatial anomalies, and mercenaries seeking to capitalize on the chaos. You play one such S.T.A.L.K.E.R. sans memories, sent back into the Zone to kill a mysterious figure close to the epicenter of it all. Along the way you'll forge alliances with other wanderers, discover threats far worse than mutated wildlife, and maybe come face to face with the source of the disaster itself. I wouldn't bank on that last one without some serious effort, though.Instead of discreet levels, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is made up of maps that connect to form one contiguous world. Starting near the border of the Zone, you'll journey through radioactive swamps, underground bunkers, ghost towns, and more as you complete jobs for the other inhabitants. Sometimes that'll mean finding a stash of bizarre artifacts, and other times it'll mean gunning down a band of killers in their hideout. There's plenty to do in the Zone even without a specific mission, as you can loot corpses, hunt hidden stashes, and locate artifacts by navigating the treacherous anomalies that can crush, shock, or maim you with little warning.All of this is accomplished from a first-person perspective, but don't expect the run-and-gun action of... anything, really. The combat in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is very much its own thing, a perpetually harrowing affair of dancing around cover, emptying magazines to only land one shot, and pumping dozens of bullets into charging beasts. Weapons in the Zone are inaccurate, difficult to use, and seemingly do no damage until you land a headshot that kills in an instant. I imagine it's more like real-world firefights than anyone would admit, but that doesn't necessarily make it fun to be eaten alive by wild dogs who dodged or shrugged off a dozen rounds.You'll want to avoid combat as much as possible, at least at first, and luckily there's a robust and effective stealth system to make use of. This system tracks your light level, posture, noises made, and even gives you bolts you can toss to cause distractions (or trigger anomalies). There's a pretty big emphasis on stats across the board, really. Your character has resistances to all kinds of injury as well as a radiation level to monitor, your inventory has weight and conditions to consider, and every single NPC in the game has a reputation rating with you. There aren't always systems that address these stats directly, but they do represent significant depth to the simulation.Attention to detail extends to the environments, and it is here that you'll find S.T.A.L.K.E.R.'s greatest strength. For a nearly ten-year-old game, the Zone looks amazing, with crumbling buildings and thick underbrush and rolling clouds blotting out the sun. There's a palpable sense of decay and instability wherever you go, and it only grows more intense as you approach the heart of the Zone. Every dark corner can hide a creature that wants your blood or an anomaly that can rend you in an instant, demanding caution and tense attention even in the daylight hours. And don't get me started on the underground bunkers... some of the most effective horror encounters I've experienced in gaming have come in the subterranean halls of the Zone.I've spent a lot of time extolling the virtues of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. because they are many, but not without a price. It is an ambitious indie game after all, and that means all sorts of potential glitches and instability whenever you load in. Sometimes the AI breaks down, sometimes items vanish from the ground, and sometimes the thing will just crash when you least expect it. Beyond that there are definitely balance issues with the weapons and combat, exacerbated by missions with no real difficulty curve to them that might send you into a hostile mercenary camp before you find anything more formidable than a sawed-off. The rough translated text might actually be the worst offender, hiding key information and names behind English one step above Google Translate in some cases.The Zone is a harsh and unforgiving place, and S.T.A.L.K.E.R. exemplifies it right down to the code. It's going to take you a long time and multiple tries to acclimate to its unique style, and turning to modding isn't a bad idea if the base game is just too daunting or janky. But once you come to grips with the combat and start learning the many ways to die in the Zone, you're in for one hell of a ride. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. does immersion and atmosphere better than almost any FPS, presenting you with a rich, frightening, living world that will fight you every step of the way.

content:
ber 22, 2015
												I’m not here to suggest you into buying it. After browsing many reviews both there and on the Metacritic, I see STALKER as a moving train. You’re either hopped on it, or not.STALKER is not your usual big entertaining AAA-title, like Crysis or Call of Duty. It is more like living Monument. For my point of view, it is even bigger than Halo franchise.  Maybe bigger than Moby ♥♥♥♥ (the Whale). And with strong Russian accent. I’m not saying that only Russian-speakers can understand this scenery, but you really have to have somewhat specific system of values and behavioural pattern, to get in tune with that game. And what pattern it could be?Let me tell you where this game takes roots. It will be much better, than usual pro/contra stuff.Okay, first, there was a book. It was written by Strugatsky brothers and called “Roadside Picnic”. In there was painted our world after a brief impact with extraterrestrial civilization. Those aliens weren't contacted with people, they just used our planet as a campsite, and then disappeared in the space, while left some garbage at their leisure. The book’s story tells about some scientist who is researching that impact by studying strange alien artifacts, which can be recovered from abnormal zones aliens left behind. Due to its completely alien nature, the most of those “campsite” zones are extremely dangerous. Just like an oil puddle for ants.After filming that scenario, directed by Andrei Tarkovsky, it turns out that the most natural and the most alive-looking character is not a day-dreaming scientist, wishing to make the world a better place. No, the main character of the movie was a simple guy, who dwelled the Zone by his instincts, intuition and luck, just for make a living for another day. The Stalker.No, that’s not the end of the history lesson. After that movie, Chernobyl catastrophe happened. It was really far from the resemblance with the “Roadside Picnic” events, but, after all impersonal cruelty that striked the territory around Chernobyl area, a big circle of the deadland was created, which fitted to the anomaly zone by its size and tragic background.And after that tragedy, there was a Soviet Union crush, which created so-called “roaming 90’s”. Ex-Soviet people, left in the dark age with squashed moral principles, which kept them together all soviet years, started a struggle of survival on the ruins of former life. It was then when bandits were ruled every activity, promising some outcome, preferably the fastest and dirtiest way possible.Finally, in the new millennia the governments of the former Union finally take some power back in their hands, so there was a time of peace in the 00’s in the Ukraine. Some talented people gather there and created a very powerful (yet not too stable) engine, and they blended Strugatsky, Tarkovsky, roaming 90’s under the shadow of Chernobyl zone…So, here you are: a simple man, who tries to get by and live another day, yet must adapt and survive in the hostile terrain. You hunt vile creatures, explore and getting used to the location, where every 10 straight steps leading you to another death trap. You collect some strange artifacts, survive encounters with bandits and hostile military forces, you helping some random and generic friendly stalkers (and even getting some help in return). And after some time, you feel yourself like at home there…Just like a soldier in his beloved trenches. Or a hunter in the wilderness, alone among wolves and bears. That’s a pattern of behaviour I was talking before. You’re not a hero in the shining armor, saving the world there. You just a survivalist, who’s getting stronger the harder fate trying to bend him. Without hope in government, in global order and justice, in helping hand from the Heaven… just to live another day.I know what not everybody could be like this. But Stalker game is giving so alive, so thrilling modus operandi that I know many people who played only in this videogame in the whole life.Inexpressible in words, unforgettable experience. Suspense. To kill or to be killed?Okay, enough with pathos. As a game, STALKER obviously has flaws. Frequent engine crushes, questionable features like constant respawn of enemies, narrow ravine between locations…But all this pales, when I remember how many time (even before Steam) I’ve spent there.So that game takes a mark 10/10 from me, for being like no other. A quintessence of a part of my life.

r 17, 2014
												cheeki breekiedit: apparently people have seen this so I feel like actually adding a reviewThis game is an atmospheric and spooky game that takes place in an alternate universe after the chernobyl incident. In this universe, the chernobyl incident created an ever expanding zone which produces deadly anomalies and horrifying creatures whose prey consist of you.You play as a STALKER, which basically is just a person who traverses the zone, who has suffered from some sort of amnesia. You only have one clear goal which is noted on your PDA: Kill Strelok.Who strelok is or why you need to kill him is unknown, but you pursue this goal in hopes of finding out why you are trying kill him and what happened to you.The game starts you in a small village with a simple goal of assisting nearby mecenaries in raiding a bandit camp, in hopes of retrieving a prisoner and a thumbdrive.It sets the tone of the game very well. You can choose to experience the more stealthy lethal approach or the loud and proud route by talking to the head merc and choosing either option.You get a quick feel for the tense gunplay (which I significantly recommend playing on max difficulty, it increases lethality for both sides during fights) and how the AI acts.The game in essence is great. Sorry if the review isnt in depth, but the game is rock solid 10/10.Though if you buy it know that you are supporting a person who practically tortured the dev team (who recieve no money from your purchase) and made them work in inhumane conditions. No matter what way you choose to get it, this game is worth your time.

content:
er 10, 2016
												This is one of my favorite games of all time.Steam says I've only got 16 hours clocked in on this, but I bought this on disc as a teenager when it first came out in 2007, and probably have well over +100 hours otherwise. Back then it was so horribly buggy and unoptimized at launch, that even while playing on the lowest settings it still chugged at 15 fps and the load times were God-awful. But even then, I was so absorbed in the world that was created here, it was unlike anything I had ever played before, that I was still completely engaged.Now, ten years on, the game has so much more to offer. There are so many mods available that you can play through the game several times and get entirely different experiences every time. The combat is slow and somewhat tactical and requires patience, and the gameplay itself is clunky, and the difficulty is somewhere between challenging and outright punishing, but you'll never play a game like this again. This is Eastern European sci-fi horror/post apocolypse at its finest.

content:
y 5, 2015
												A likeable open world game that is set in a post apocalyptic environment. It is  filled with merciless human scum, religious fanatics that wouldn't care less if a nonbeliever is to die, and vicious mutants. No matter where you go, the choices you make in fighting to survive can impact you.What the game did right:There are diverse NPCs that roam around the game. Their interactions with other friends/neutral characters and enemies are almost unscripted, thus making gameplay unique. The atmopshere of  S.T.A.L.K.E.R is unforgettable and is the most memoriable. The weather and "day and night" system constantly changes which can either make you relaxed or downright terrified. For example, enjoy being with other friendly/neutral characters by hanging around with them near a fire or be trembling in fear within a dark underground system. You can't relax for a couple of seconds when bypassing enemy lines or breaching a room that could be filled with a hostile mutant. Combat in this game will never bore you, and can be just as brutal. As a result, you can't just rush in with guns blazing if sufficient support is nonexistant as a shotgun to the face is lethal, even on easy difficulty. There's plenty of weapons in this game, Expand your average arsenal to a powerful gauss rifle or a grenade launcher. Show no mercy and obliterate your foes to mere chunks of flesh. Upgraded weapons are also present which are usually different from their ordinary cousins. The concept of artifacts and anomalies are intriguing. Equip some and you can sprint iinfinitely (if you are light enough) or regenerate health. Treasure hunters will love this, no doubt about it. Main tasks can be delayed to complete other smaller tasks to obtain money or simply explore the landscape. Unlike most games, how and where you move can impact your survival. Sneaking through bushes can allow you to remain concealed but creates sounds. Even if limited, the community of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has been dedicated to modding, thus you can seek to replace your weapon skins or expand your experience with the Zone. I did love this game but many issues, like technical problems, didn't make me favor this game overall. What the game should have fixed/improved on:S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is plagued with bugs and glitches. This really hampers on how enjoyable the game is. Some objectives aren't possible to complete or can confuse and frustrate players. For me, the worst bug I encountered was being forced to fight hostile loners in the Duty base and after killing them, I had a mix of Duty members who were friends and enemies. This game also stutters quite often, which isn't present in Clear Sky. Some good weapons are (almost) impossible to obtain, because they were cut from the game, are only avaliable at certain places/vendors, or must be taken by killing certain NPCs.Adding to the aforementioned problem, weapons and armor degrade over time, especially unique equipment. You can repair armor with the right artifacts and specific anomaly but weapons have to be replaced. Moreover, this game has a "weapon jam" system thus one has to eventually give in and buy a new firearm or can get lucky by salvaging a pristine weapon off a dead enemy. The weight limit can become very annoying. Often times, the limit in carrying weapons is 3 and it's painful to go back to a stash that has more suitable weapons when you cannot win a fight if the right firearms are not present. Despite claiming to be a RPG game, players have very little choice in implementing free will in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. In other words, you're forced to play as the same character without making any decisions that can change the storyline. Stealth in this game is fairly broken. Enemies may still notice you, even if one is to quietly move around or sneak behind a target, while other times an NPC can be killed but other AI controlled characters will not notice it. Certain NPCs can be made into friends by helping them when wounded or doing certain tasks but there's barely any difference when they were originally neutral to you. It's a shame that you can't recruit them to fight alongside your presence. In many cases, how NPCs spawn (or where you enter a map) is often stupid. One time, I exited out fo the underground and a group of bandits greeted me by killing me instantly and I couldn't do anything. Other times, killed foes are out of the map boundaries which makes looting their corpses impossible.Furthermore, even though some enemies are supposed to ignore the player and fight each other, they may actually team up and attempt to kill you, such as when mutants are fighting mercenaries. The minor tasks in this game have a time limit (one day of game time). This is a problem because some jobs take a lot of time to complete (such as eliminating ALL members of an opposing force without help or going to the other side of the map). Moreover, you have to claim a reward quickly otherwise, you will be penalized and your reputation may go down (though, because of the huge glitches, it probably won't matter that much as it constantly changes). Shamefully, you cannot fast travel. Some argue it should not be implemented in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. but the Zone is huge and to make a simple trip can take a long time, due to the dangers that are present in a pathway.Finally, the plot is just ok. It has good suspense but it's pretty slow (depending on how fast you want to pass through the game) and the exploration can be distracting. Other:Multiplayer is still around, but there's only a few servers that have just a handful of players. For me, they all have a ping of more than 200. Conclusion:The game is overpriced, considering the bugs that the game suffers from. It should have priced at either $10 or $15. If it wasn't for that, I would highly recommend this game. You can try to mod this game but beyond changing the skins of textures, you are more likely to face crashes than success. In the end, it's a good game if you can get pass through the cons that I mentioned.

er 26, 2016
												People are creating reviews on why this game is hard and the aspects of why so i figure i'll make one to and my viewpoints on why. First off, the game isn't very hard in the combat area once you learn the how to do the combat, once thing is, you'll die, a lot in the beginning and a little more when automatics are introduced BUT combat is also fun for the fact that it's unpredictable in a sense. Where did that bandit go that you were firing at? Well he din't stand still like every other (low end) shooter out there, he coordinated with his allies and moved to a position where they could out flank you. Now where I find it challenging is keeping another friendly npc alive. So far into my four hour gameplay almost all "quest" npcs have died, but dont worry because it has alternates incase of this happening. Never played a Stalker game but i can kill more by myself than with a four man team. Dont get me wrong, I've been having a hell of a time having fun here but dear god, can this game be unforgiving. It's a great 8/10 game for people who like games where they don't hold your hand in survival but if your edgy or freak out if you die with very little explaination on how, it isn't very recommended. Now I highly doubt somebody's actually reading this so as bonus for reading this review, you get this invisible potato from the zone, giving you +20 radiation but infinite health bonus, enjoy the game ;).

												Quite possibly the best game I have played in a long while. The game itself is challenging with loads of NPCs who are quite capable of giving you a run for your money. They will almost always try to stay in cover and even flank you (including mutants). The game offers a massive open world with a variety of places to explore. The storyline is marvelous, full of intrigue and is guaranteed to get you hooked and the variety of side quests will never let you get bored. Various factions react differently to your actions so keeping all of the Zone happy is tricky, but well worth it.The shooting part of the game is realistic. Weapons can get stuck and can shoot blanks as well. From afar you won’t be able to hit jack ♥♥♥♥, but point blank, damage output is massive (especially with shotguns, go figure).There are a few bugs, I am not gonna lie, such as some graphic issues, NPCs can get stuck inside of walls and obstacles etc.And of course, best Cheeki Breeki experience.Bottom line, if you’re looking for a good story and a game where you can explore I would highly recommend this as pros largely outweigh the cons. 9/10

content:
er 3, 2013
												It's the year 2013 close to 2014 now and this is still my favourite game. You start as a guy who lost his memory and all you have is a STALKER tatoo on your forearm and a PDA with the task "KILL THE STRELOK".The game offers a great fps experience with some rpg elements combined with a great variety of weapons,suits and medium sized maps filled with mutanats, anomalies and dangerous underground laboratories that host mutated experiments and documents that clear things out for people in the Zone. The Zone is the closed area around the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant where this game takes place. The Zone is split in different places controlled by factions that you can ignore,attack or help but beware, once you attack 1 npc from that faction you're going to be at war with them and they will attack you on sight.(except The Monolith faction, they are enemies to all) During gameplay the user will encounter strange glowing balls in the fields or near anomalies, these are called artefacts and can be used to boost your resists.By following the quest line you will find out the true meaning of your forearm tatoo,the reason of The Zone and how The Zone was created. It may seem logical to do all the main quests but it becomes tricky at a certain point and people seem to ignore this part and just move forward.This leads to the 5 false endings  but if the user pays attention he is rewarded with extra gameplay, 2 more endings and THE TRUTH behind all of this.Yes the game has 7 endings, the 2 real endings and 5 false endings based on decisions throughout the game ( check Google for decisions ).People usually ignore this game when they see Release Date: 20 Mar 2007, good,their mistake.Personally I recommend new players to play this game vanilla and get the real taste of being a STALKER after that you can patch it and have fun, enjoy better textures and explore every corner of The Zone.Pros-all from aboveCons-some bugs-can fall out of game map in certain areas-too easy to get money,med kits,bandages etc.-in cleared areas mutants/npcs respawn probably killing some of your "friends"-no way to repair weapons/suits (except mods ) etc.BUT this is no problem for a true STAKLER.Now GET OUT OF HERE STALKER and play the game.

number of helpful: 35 of 37 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 26, 2014
												Stalker is a series that is somehow both ahead of its time and dated simultaneously. Graphically the game isn't, and never was, the hottest thing on the market. However, the world that they dev. team have created is one of the most genuinely sinister and oppressive that I have ever experienced in a game. The creatures are disturbing and dangerous, and the lighting (particularly in the darkness) effectively creates a creeping, relentless tension. The moment in the tunnels when you look back and see the silhouette of the Controller emerge for the first time (seasoned players will know what I mean) is one of the most unnerving experiences I can recall having.Like all the games in the series, Stalker doesn't coddle its players. Starting the game is quite brutal as it can take a new player some time to come to grips to the realism of the gunplay and the initially unforgiving difficulty of the enemies. The bullet physics are realistic in that your weapons aren't perfectly accurate, nor are they entirely reliable, and misfires can be common with weapons of a low condition, so you must use your brain and know your weapons and their limitations before initiating a firefight. In saying that, the game rewards the player by lightening the load as you progress and get better weapons and armour, and by the mid-point the difficulty can lessen considerably.The sound is here and there in terms of quality, with the voice acting being average and flat a lot of the time, however, the atmospheric sound, weapon sounds, and THAT droning voice towards the end (seasoned players will understand), really plant a disturbing and terrifying chill in your spine the whole way through. Voice acting aside, the sound in these games are one of my favourite parts. Stalker: SoC is a game I keep coming back to replay again and again, not in the least because of the quality of the mods out there. In saying that, the world that the devs have created and the emotions that that world inspires in me remains with me for long after every play session, and I think that, once one gets past the initial hurdles that the game places in front of you, this is one of the best post-apocalyptic games I've ever played. I feel that, whereas classics like Bioshock (for a random example) are fantastic games that appeal to everyone, cult classics are fantastic games that are an acquired taste. This is very much, in my mind, the absolute definition of cult classic. I highly recommend it (with a good mod like COMPLETE if you wish to smooth the creases out) to anyone looking for a deep, memorable and unsettling FPS experience.

content:
9, 2016
												Honestly, I understand not everyone may like it, its dated and at times clunky or cheesey, confusing even and sometimes frustrating, but if youre able to overlook the simple flaws it has, beneath is an incredible gem of a game.Its based (very loosely) on the Russian novel "Roadside Picnic" by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky.(Which is a fantastic novel Id also recommend)I have yet to play the sequels but Ive heard this is the best of the games. There is also a movie titled "stalker" that once again loosely shares a similar plot to the games and novel.The atmosphere and chills the game produces is fantastic.It actually scared me senseless at sometimes and the enemies you fight are unique and interesting, even if you may tire of killing them over and over as there isnt too much variety, but the game remains fresh by supplying you with new weapons, locations, items, artifacts, armour and other loot that keeps you sastified throughout your playthrough.The look of the Zone and the areas around it are incredible. You feel a sense of dread and fascination as you walk into open areas filled with destroyed facilities, communications stations, army bases, abandoned towns and villages, Stalker camps and strongeholds, safe zones and pieces of land scorched by anomalies that will turn you into paste or burn you alive.Very fun exploration too as the Zone just looks great. Collecting artifacts and making profit feels rewarding and the battles are nerve gripping at times. Play with headphones at night for best experience (seriously though)There are basic survival needs as well, the character must eat periodically, bandages are used to stop bleeding, medkits heal greater wounds and later on radiation, infections, burns etc. Some enviromental suits protect against these things too. Different ammo types for practically every type of weapon..I could go on and on, but you really should just try it for yourself!Definitely worth it!It usually goes on sale quite often too, so grab it during one and youll save a bunch!

number of helpful: 37 of 42 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
er 6, 2013
												Let´s start. Why is this my favorite game of all time? The answer is quite easy. It has everything I expect from a top notch shooter. It has unique compelling gameplay, the most immersive atmosphere I ever experienced in a videogame, it´s open world and it has addictive RPG elements. Even factions and a really great story. The reason this game flawed was that it had so many bugs. FREAKIN MANY. After years of patching and fanpatches it finally become stable and accessible for casuals. I don´t recommend to play it without thecommunity fixes which are called "Zone Reclamation Project" since I´m not sure if you would like purest vanilla of da stalker. Let´s go into the details and sort it out for you.Graphics, Technical Aspects:The original Stalker was really great looking but it already had its weaknesses. While textures and dynamic lighting were fantastic, the lighting in specific is even better than in some modenr games due to it being 100% real time but the animations and graphical bugs were bad though. Shadows were sometimes really ugly and unrealistic but it was rarer. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky though had some sick high shadow resolutions and realistic lighting! Beautiful landscapes setting the mood perfectly in all of the Stalker games. Back to SoC. Textures were really High Res for it´s time and everything else was top notch too. Animations were mostly robotic but they didn´t give you eye cancer. Guns were looking good and the skybox was incredible. The game was oozing with atmosphere and east european charm. It felt immersive and realistic. The complete mod even made the game looking sweet for today´s standards, adding bump mapping and steep parallax at buildings and streets. They worked and made the game even more immersive and realistic. With Complete Mod 2012 it looks polished and very good but it also overhauls the game balancing too much and make it too easy for the game´s survival aspect. There was also the single core focused engine and the sun shadow bug. The game loses it´s beautiful lighting if you turn off Sun Shadow since it´s turning off the sun. Dumb. It still looks amazing though. I don´t know if the Complete Mod fixed this graphic bug for everyone. It´s a shame that the engine creates this bug with newer graphic cards and drivers. World, Atmosphere, AI, Gameplay and Locations:Like said, the landscapes were breathtaking and are still beautiful today if updated with the Complete Mod and even more so with Autumn Aurora 2.1. The atmosphere is already explained: It´s stunning and immersive, it won´t let you go away. It grabs you and whispers you in your ear: "I know you love me, I saw you fapping. Marry me!" Nuff said. The combination between the world, the free roaming AI, gripping atmosphere and RPG elements (which I will discuss later on in my review) are going hand in hand, creating one of the best gaming experiences I ever had. It builds Nostalgia like a chinese construction worker builds a skyscraper even if the game balancing was quite unbalanced at some points and had some quest breaking bugs. Side quests only though. Devs made sure the main missions work. Autumn Aurora though has a endgame bug where a save goies corrupt. So be aware with Autumn Aurora and save alot.I have to tell you about the AI though. It was the problem many had with this game. It was bugged, unpredictable and just plain bad. Just quicksave often. Yes this game is so oldschool it still has the good old quicksave function and due to tough fights it´s necessary. I don´t know why it died. It´s a useful feature even for today´s times. Consoles.... And in this game it´s an elementary function to avoid frustration and anger. ^^´. Finished 3 dudes without having a scratch? Quicksave. Or don´t do it and make it extra hard for yourself. The locations are self explained. Eastern European places like industrial complexes and open places with borders, huge dumps of metallic garbage, discarded train stations, underground research labs with secret experiments, etc....and of course the highlights. PRIPYAT AND THE NUCLEAR POWER PLANT. Atmosphere overdose. Especially at night with all the terrifying mutants around you.Even though the AI can be stupid as ♥♥♥♥ sometimes, as long as they don´t wallhack and annoy the crap out of you with their deadly accuracy and one hit headshot deaths, they are sometimes even very smart, taking cover, throwing grenades, luring you out of covers and sometimes even silently flanking you. It´s a very strange AI. Definitely better than this linear CoD campaign AI ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and a lot, A LOT more thrilling and challenging than in most games. Different enemy types from different factions, fighting each other and you of course. Establishing a great universe. The gunplay needs an overhaul with Autumn Aurora or Arsenal Overhaul though as it´s issue with more inaccurate weapons were that the bullets sprayed too randomly to have fake sprays in and out of ADS to simulate the weapon weathering as guns have health, as does armor,etc. It takes too long talking about every gameplay aspect here, watch a youtube vid. Because there are so many hella lot of aspects. I just told you the only big issue with gunplay, the rest is fine but can be improved with recommended mods really. It´s fun with vanilla already, but with mods it´s absolutely epic and godlike. Check out this as an example, not a recommendation as there are better ones outthere: 


YouTube™ Video: Stalker shadow of chernobyl fotograf + weapons mod 

			Views: 19,856		

			Here is a show case of some the weapons in the mod. NOTE: Professor Kruglov mission "place detectors in anomalies" has a bug where you cannot not complete it.		

If you intend to mod make sure to inform yourself properly and backup your files.  Modding is worth it but can be difficult sometimes and generally wonky too if done not properly. Depends from mod to mod.Horror, Survival, RPG Elements and Dialogues:The atmosphere brings up a more unknown part of the game. Horror. At some parts this game freaked me out, even though after I played several horror games very often. Mutants like the bloodsuckers which can make themselves invisible, are giving you the creeps. A strong paranoia is common in quiet parts. Cry of fearish. Combined with the RPG elements it makes a great survival game too. You have an inventory you need to manage. Different ammunition types with different effects, many guns and a lot of different calibers, suppressors, scopes, modifications, PDA with quests and even an ingame encyclopedia. What I want to say is that this game has a lot of content and the game length is easily 20 hrs if you mod... it grow infinite. The dialogue in the game is good at most times and often even funny but you have to read, ok? There are voiced ones but mostly you have to read. So have patience or skip but then miss out on the most of the story. You can miss SO MUCH by skipping. And yes the dialogue isn´t much, loads of reading and it can be ome bad writing, but it non the less grips and entertains everytime.Endings:There are several endings. The bad ending with the wishgranter and the true endings. In order to save your ♥♥♥ from getting the bad ending or the bad true ending follow these steps:Do your side missions. Not the small quests, only major sidequests. Before going to the brainscorcher, meet with the guide in order to get to meet the doctor. The true true ending can only be achieved by not agreeing with a certain nature to join their program. The rest would be spoiling.Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat:Shadow of Chernobyl is the best part for beginners and rookie stalkers to begin with. Don´t go into the other two since Call of Pripyat has a totally different story and Clear Sky needs some knowledge as it´s an prequel that connects storywise to Shadow of Chernobyl in its own way.Conclusion:Low priced highly moddable masterpiece with quite the flaws that still shines brighter than a shooting star at the ukrainian nightsky. Grab if you feel like loving and entering the genius art and world of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.

content:
er 21, 2014
												Hundreds of hours invested in this on the disc version purchased many moons ago. STALKER is a bleak, nightmareish vision brought to life even more so with the huge collection of community made mods available. This was the first game in the trilogy of games the other two being Call of Pripyat and Clear Sky (a prequal). Both of which are also incredible, CoP more so.When you leave the Cordon for the first time after speaking to Wolf, walking up that path towards the road, turning and seeing your brothers slowly disappear into the distance, hearing the wind howl around the barrel of your creaky old shotgun, suddenly hearing some sort of demonic cry far away to the east and a chill creeps down your back. The sun is low in the musty sky - but just up ahead there is an old abandoned mill to explore, just make use of the fading light.For me this game creates an atmosphere I've never felt before (or since, other STALKER titles not including) of a world gone to hell - the Zone, a huge area of land around the defunct Chernobyl reactor, now infested with nightmareish creatures deformed by radiation, different collections of (human) mostly factions wanting to kill you on sight and rob your last tin of tuna. Secret underground labs where horrific experiments happened before everything went to hell. Deserted farm buildings where blood hungry things lurk in the dark. STALKER is all about tension and fear, but also survival.There are mods you can get that improve just about every aspect of the original game, textures, weapons, music, audio, bugs ironed out, even previously unnavailble areas.I love STALKER, it's tremendously satisfying to survive in the Zone, it's terrifying, compelling and full of detail (if you also read all of lore/diary entries that Marked One enters into your PDA throughout the game.For anybody that likes FPS/open world survival shooters with strong RPG elements, for anybody that loves to become really immersed in their chosen universe, there is nothing quite like STALKER.Just don't forget your anti rads, and take care of Nimble - he's worth it.

content:
r 25, 2014
												With one of the greatest cult followings of all time, fantastic mod support, a wonderful setting, and cheesy Russian voice acting, the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is one that may have been surpassed by some, but is definitely worth the $15. Like most post-apoctalyptic games, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.'s harsh Russian wasteland and mutated animals provide a brooding backdrop for the game. However, unlike most games of the genre, this one's story is something that brings a little extra novelty to the game (the game is based off of the 1972 classic, Roadside Picnic.[www.amazon.com]) Along with this, there was also a movie, which is aptly named Stalker, which was released in 1979. You can read more about that here.[www.imdb.com] The story revolves around the Chernobyl nuclear diasaster in 1986. In the story, the radiation spread much quicker, the effects being much more devastating. Now, radiation storms and rocks, all under the name "anomalies", were scattered across the landscape. To get more into the actual game, the gunplay is actually somewhat satisfying. The game is a first person shooter, with elements of an inventory, as well as enemies dropping rare weapons, or better weapons, as well as food, bandages, etc. Akin to games such as DayZ or Arma, the shooting mechanics are meant to be more realistic in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. You bleed at various severities depending on where and how much you have been hit, and you must use bandages to stop the bleeding and heal yourself (food is another option to regain health). Your gun can (and will) jam, and ammo is scarce (even scarcer with some friendly mods). The AI is probably the most lacking of all the gameplay aspects, as their grenade lobbing and intense corner camping can lead to some awkward firefights (the quicksave button is nice). The game revolves around this faction, known as Stalkers. These are freelance men, almost like prospectors, to find valuables deep within the Zone (the area in and around the Chernobyl factory.) Being a Stalker is a dangerous job, which can turn many to a darker side. The Russian Army has become a shell of its former self, now a greedy army looking for power. Factions such as the Duty attempt to rally against this army. Like any good post-apoc game, there are of course low level mercaneries too, there to spoil the fun and become some nice target practice. There are of course more factions, but why spoil them all here? You can read all about them in the ingame PDA. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. holds a place dear in my heart. Many have played it, and it is definitely an inspiration for many popular games today. The definition of a cult classic, this game (as well as the series) is something to be cherished.

content:
er 25, 2015
												Classic game from 2007 Inspired by the book called Roadside Picnic, cult following is still active to this day and refining and redesigning everything there is S.T.A.L.K.E.R.Before anything else, the retail russian copies of Shadow of Chernobyl came with patches 1.0001/2 and filled with absolutely everything worst to have in a game, bugs, crashes, gamebreaking issues as time went on other european countries and the US have their on retail CD's of stalker containing patch 1.0005/6 but essentially have fixed various things from 3 and 4, 1.0005 and 6 were only multiplayer patches and fixes.Don't be dithered on trying the game out as its old, graphics is grody, not more 'user' friendly as newer games. as I can say Shadow of Chernobyl's lighting, weather, god rays, particle effects absolutely can blow any modern games out of the water being well done even on vanilla.  Alot of veterans would say "atmosphere this, atmosphere that, atmosphere everywhere!" Yes, that is the case. S.T.A.L.K.E.R.'s atmosphere is the selling point of the game with dynamic A-LIFE(AI) going on about the map/level things are dynamic, life goes on every hour and minute, your buddies, friends, fellow faction member can die at any given and they will not stand around in a spot like most games, Various quest and task can fail if ignored or levels can be and will be more harder if everything is well. The first instances the game treats you as another soul not knowing what to do in the game, Do not worry You will die and die until you realize you can be doing things much more faster and efficient. The AI in this game is different from others, They can be Amazing and shoot their sawn offs across the horizons or bug out and get stuck in various forms of hilarity but that does not hinder them from being difficult. The zone is a dangerous place, pockets of radiation lingering, uneven ground, chemical spills or "Anomalies" that produces different kinds of hazards and also produces rare things called "Artifacts" that gives off various stat changes like take less bleeding, absorbing radiation with some having negative effects to counteract the positives. New players will have a gripe on how hard the game is or have no clue on what to do from the realism and gunplay as you will need to try to get another tier before leaving rookie village. ALOT of people will suggest to install mods like complete mod to even out the game and make it more decent but I will ask you to refrain from doing that as it ruins the fun and gameplay of stalker while yes people have opinions on it and the base game itself I will not judge you but I will say that if you did install complete mod there is two snorks profusely laughing and shaking their heads from the doing you have made while a bandit spinning in a whirligig is laughing and saying "AH, SHYA MI WAM ARATI NIDALENIJINI" before exploding. Mod talkI must say that it does take some brain to actually edit stuff and play around with configs and actually test you if you know how to use a keyboard besides eating paste and drinking mountain dew as you call in airstrikes for your yearly rehash game. Almost anything can be done in stalker, don't like the vanilla UI or making it more minimal? edit the HUD files. Want your guy to hide his weapon when healing? Edit the .ltx. Do you want another game that looks totally different from stalker altogether? Go crazy and feel the magic.While the average player would not really touch this second and disregard it as they just want to play their games as touching this section of your game will be absolutely life changing, You will not look at stalker the same way as before your first playthrough. some may suggest Autumn Aurora 2 for Shadow of Chernobyl if they absolutely refuse to play vanilla/ZRP(Zone Reclamation Project) for their first being AA2 is an upgrade on graphics and gunplay, there are many mods such as Doom's Mod Merge, or Zone of Alienation even STALKERSOUP that added kitchen sinks. There are hundreds of untranslated mod for stalker in ap-pro or any other stalker sites that could be categorize as bad, decent, decently bad or amazing. 99% of the time spent for stalker is modding[puu.sh] your game to have mods on top of mods and making it work, As after you're done it will be amazing and fun, catered to your liking.if anything I will absolutely say S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is PC gaming at its finest, this is what is all about, modding to the extent new content is still being made after years and various iterations and improvements the community has given to the series, Really wonderful and talented people.Helpful stuffSo you want to buy stalker? if possible, get the GoG[www.gog.com] version or you already got the game? redeem a non DRM version for free here[www.gog.com]Can someone explain what all of this in the HUD mean?[a.pomf.cat]Game Modificationhttp://www.moddb.com/games/stalkerZone Reclamation Projecthttp://www.metacognix.com/stlkrsoc/index.htmlZone Survival Guidehttp://zsg.dk/Guide by Spartan and dusty_thoreau


The Zone Manual: Every Mod You'll Ever Need for the True Ukrainian Experience 
A Guide for S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl
By: dusty_thoreau

			So, you just stepped into a Steam sale, or someone has gifted you S.T.A.L.K.E.R. eh? Well, maybe we can help you. Just pour yourself a glass of Cossacks Vodka, and pray you survive the next blowout, rookie.		


Set your game difficulty on masters for immersion and actual difficulty. Remove crosshairs, you do not need it. (optional) disable map radar via hud edits, you do not need it but some people would like to see where they are or dead bodies(map tells the story more than anything)Good hunting, stalker enjoy the zone and have a great time. (wew, shameless plug here, I do encourage people to be self reliant, get into stalker modding, and help others if they have game problems)

content:
21, 2015
												I used to hate this game, really I did. But I decided to give it another chance, and, I motherfudging love this game.Can't beleive I used to hate this game to be honest, I just love how the mechanics work and the general gameplay is enjoyable.The general disaproval of my original review (that was negative, bashing the game for the wrong reasons) persuaded me to give it another go, and I'm glad I did.____________________________________________________________Pros:Cheeki Breeki.Great combat.Good ladder physics (I hate using ladders in the normal valve game, I'll slip and fall down to my death, or get gravely injured 9 times out of ten, but I never got screwed over by a ladder in this game before.)Fantastic weapons.Decent graphics.Cool storyline (I originally thought it was boring, but at the time I never really got too involved in the storyline in the first place, you need to actually be invested in the tale itself, to be willing to experience it, in order to enjoy the story.)Voiceacting is usually good, there are a few lines that are cheesy and a little underdone, but it's overall enjoyable.Clothing and armor systems are very well made, the fact that you have to scavenge and trade for armors or be naked against the vicious wastelands just adds to the tension, which I will get to later.Challenge: this was originally something I hated about the game, but I realised that living in a nuclear infested wasteland, in the middle of Northern Ukraine wouldn't be so easy. And it isn't.Tension: I constantly find myself with my face glued to the screen, focusing on capturing a bandits' base, or clearing a military site from all inhabitants. The general suspence of the story and action gives a good vibe and leaves you wanting more.Food mechanics: Usually games have an out of place or annoying way to tell you that you are litterally dying of malnutrition. Beeping, etc. There would normally be a huge bar or meter that takes up 50% of your hud and just sits there ticking away, dangling over your head.While SoC likes to just display a tiny window telling you to eat. And when you eat, it goes away. Simple.Scare Factor: I originally disliked the scare factor and claimed it wasn't scary at all, butthat was before I got into the underground levels. My seat has the urination of 7+ underground levels soaked into it.First impression: First time I played this game I just looked at the begining cutscene, uninterested, unhyped.I didn't even pay attention to it, I just critisized and gawked at the old graphics and continued on my marry little way.But I never analyzed it for what it was, and now that I have I give it a good rating.____________________________________________________________Cons:Questionable physics engine, Props, corpses and objects will slide and bump around sometimes, breaking immersion and generaly being buggy.Silly and dumb AI. Usually I'll find bandits or military personel, mutants, friendlies, etc. Staring at walls, shooting ceilings, crouching for no good reason. Sometimes I'll see them killing themselves or other friends really for no actual reason, either. Other times they'll be shouting and screaming while crouched in a corner. The AI really act strange during combat, even not in combat as well.Enemies, including mutants, will sometimes be in the middle of attacking me and suddenly not care, strolling in the other direction like nothing happened, in their normal voices and walking as if in a passive enviroment. Even during heated gunfights with other npcs, there will always be at least one guy strolling around like there arent grenades and bullets flying past his head.One time. I started killing a few bandits near a fire, and as I offed them, the remaining 4 started shouting combat lines, shooting at me, flinching from gunfire, all behaving normally during a gunfight, as they should. Suddenly, they hostler their guns, turn around, and sit near the fire, singing, laughing, playing instruments, drinking vodka, eating sausages, talking to eachother and joking.  While I had just killed their entire squad in front of them I proceeded to jump in front of them and they continued and even made eye contact with me, I shot one of them in the foot, ran in circles around them and they still never moved an inch. I got fed up and threw a grenade at one of them. They still continued to act idly as they shouted their grenade lines, still sitting down, exploded and died.____________________________________________________________This is where the Review ends, my conclusion as that this is an overall great game, a strong 9.3/10  TL;DR section: Dis game is güd, now go buy it with money.

content:
r 26, 2014
												Awesome open-world FPS.  A little rough around the edges and glitchy, but still a great game.  The game is over 7 years old, so it is a little dated as well.  The game takes place in "The Zone", referring to the uninhabitable area surrounding the Chernobyl nuclear power station.  You start the game as a man with amnesia.  Throughout the game, you try to piece together who you are.  Within The Zone, there are anomalies, bandits, mutants, and treasure.  You have a lot of choice in the game.   You can use something loud like an AK-47 or you can try and be stealthy. The only real problem I have with this game (besides the glitches and other bugs) is that it is very difficult at the start.  You start with a pistol and some food, so it is difficult to kill the bandits/soldiers who have much better weapons than you at the start of the game. Overall, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a flawed yet fun open-world FPS.
