Just bewarn if your PC begins to lag and freeze alot. the easiest solution is to run the game on 'low' graphical settings. "Lost Alpha" it is a standalone modification based upon the S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. It will offer old features seen within the game series, While offering never before scene features within the game that in the modders opinion is a 'must needed'. I highly recommend this game for the post-apocalyptic gamer. Plain and simple

content:
8, 2014
												THIS GAME IS GREAT!!Once upon a time, Doom and Fallout had a baby, and then gave it steroids. A lot of it. And thus, STALKER was born.STALKER is an amazing series, with three games in the series, I have several days on this game, but Steam doesn't show it because I was offline while I played it. (Since I had no internet access at the time.)With a huge map to explore, plenty of monsters to face, a large assortment of weapons, armor, and missions to do, this makes for a fun time.STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is an open world FPS game. Taking place in the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone. Did you read that?!  THE FREAKIN' Chernobyl Exclusion Zone!  I even bolded it, just to show how awesome that is. The game is not creepy in a sense, but if you are prone to being frightened easily, a few areas of the game may give you a slight scare. Pros: Bro, this game takes place in Chernobyl, that's awesome in itself!A huge map to explore.Plenty of missions to do.I large assortment of weapons and armor.Treasure hunting!Immense variety of enemies.Different atmospheres and moods of tone.A few scary and eerie places in the map.A nice story. (Could use improvement.)Challenging gameplay.Good graphics.Moddable.But, of course, like all games, STALKER has some downsides we can't dismiss:The game is highly buggy and glitchy. I had a big problem getting the game to work, and I still don't have it working fully. LONG LOAD TIMES:  The load times are atrocious, and without doing some tweaking work, it will typically last from 10-15 minutes. Although settings can be changed, and mods can be installed to help this issue, it's still a problem. While the game loads, go take a shower, clean the house, or mow the lawn, it needs to be done anyways.If you don't mind bugs and glitches, sit down, grab yourself some Cossack's Vodka, put on your Russian hat,  bring a bear into your house  buckle up, and enjoy the awesome ride this game has to offer!PS: Don't actually bring a bear into your house.

content:
, 2016
												This game is like a Hotline Miami, you hate all the enemies and how much youll die but its so much fun at the same time.Came to a camp with a single guy playing the guitar, left. Came back to the same camp and the guy was dead.Came back to the same camp later on and two more guys were there, left. came back for the fourth time, one of them were dead. No enemies for miles. Pripyat/10This game isnt like fallout where it tells you what you need and where you need to get it. You need to read up on some of the mechanics and make sure whatever you have on you is enough to get you through the next zone, or you'll land flat on your ♥♥♥ and find yourself loading a quicksave... again. The AI is abnormally stupid and will often hit you flawlessly whereas you could use the same exact gun and youd be lucky to hit the broad side of a barn. The enemies are repetitive and seems like you're just in a mod for half life with a rusty reskin. The atmosphere is amazing though. There are many times where the task would be to go underground and I'd be frustrated because of the closed spaces and Snorks (sp00ky mutants with gas masks) could be waiting for you to..... spin around in endless circles. The AI is unbalanced aswell. During a side quest where you can help a faction called the Duty, where you have to raid a military and I ended up taking on the base by myself and not even getting the reward for the task because my commanding officer was dead.Pros:-Atmosphere-Vodka-Sausage-Guns-Story????Cons:-Unbalanced AI-No quick radiation button-Inaccurate guns-No fast travel-Repetitive enemies-Wonky AI (Will often run in circles)Overall:восемь из десяти (8/10)Conclusion:This game is blatantly broken in some aspects, pop ins, OP enemies. But this game can do one thing that Fallout couldnt do in a post apocalyptic franchise, Scare me. Make me feel the cold in Russia. I personally couldnt finish this game due to not having the right armor but i was literally 5 feet away from the ending cutscene so watching the ending on YT was good enough. You will rage at this game, but its all in good fun.

												HOW TO SOLVE THE RESOLUTION BUG: when you start the game, it has a very low resolution, and changing this results in a crash. all you need to do is select the correct resolution, but do NOT click use yet! instead, first go to advanced options, and THEN click use. that worked for me.I have only played this game for about 3 hours now, but I can safely say that this game is amazing! just ignore the old graphics(you can always download a graphics mod if it is really bothering you) and you've got an amazing game. it is very immersive and gets you quite scared sometimes, but in an immersive way, not like actual horror.it has got some bugs though, especially the animal AI is not very good(wild dogs often just walk right past me) and guns are VERY inaccurate, but generally a great purchase.

content:
, 2014
												This might probably be the most immersive and atmospheric shooter I have played to this day. Its strength mostly comes from the design of the world. You will see abandoned industrial districts, large radioactive wastelands and dark underground complexes with enemies, possibly around each corner. When travelling around the world you will encounter all kinds of characters: Neutral Stalkers, just like you, who are travelling the Zone looking for artifacts and trying to survive, Bandits who ambush you, trying to kill and loot you, or members of many different factions, which can be friendly or hostile, depending on your actions.The world itself is very open and unscripted. Pretty much anything can happen, depending on who or what you will encounter. I want to tell a funny story about that:I once took a sidequest which told me to kill a random target (These kind of quests are quite common and sometimes very challenging). Having a look on my map I saw that my target was very far away, so on my way there I did few different things. When I finally reached the sector, I saw a man in the distance being attacked and ripped apart by a horde of mutant dogs. In the second of his death I got the message that my quest was completed and returned for my undeserved reward.

content:
y 22, 2015
												I enjoy Deus Ex and System Shock 2 as much as the next person, but for me S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernoybl towers over the first-person shooter genre.It's that chilling feeling gotten by wondering across the bleak open landscape while hearing dogs howling in the distance (this being one of the very few games to be able to pull off outdoor daylight horror), It's that weird moment when you see some invisible monster for the first time and realise the game's surreal underbelly. It's the beautiful atmosphere created by the lightning. It's the tension built by running around trying to find that one last bit of radiation protection before you die of radiation poisoning. It's that feeling of satisfaction when you finally manage to fight your way through a group of clever AI enemies, or the stress built by panickingly trying to drink enough energy drink to simply run through them. Or, more broadly - it's the perfect mixture of challenging difficulty, fantastic atmosphere and great survival mechanics which make it so special.The game builds itself on creating tension through its inventory management system and creates such perfect results through it. Funnily enough, early in the game I found it annoying that managing your inventory doesn't pause the game and sometimes I stopped dead in the middle of combat because I was too heavy to move, but by the end I realised that was such an incredible way of building tension. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is, after all, a game of scavenging and half the fun of the game is about deciding whether you can afford to go over to pillage a befallen enemy, work out what you need to take and if it's not too heavy to carry without getting killed.But great survival mechanics and a really well balanced difficulty don't make a game on its own and the other main thing which really makes S.T.A.L.K.E.R. stand out is its gameworld. It's such a beautiful, desolate overworld and as much enjoyment as the challenge was just running over the baron plains with dogs howling and boars roaming around with some odd shots in the background. Even, the main homehub of Rostock has this incredibly eerie and desolate feel about it.There's just this exquisite balance of challenge and ambience which make this the perfect FPS. Played alone, at night with headphones it is quite the experience.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 3, 2014
												STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is a game based entirely on the gameplay provided, as well as it's difficulty that stems from it's mechanics, and the hazards laid throughout the zone. The design, be it in the environment seemingly crafted from real-life examples to great detail, or the monsters themselves, as well as the great balance of guns and their somewhat realistic portraits conveyed through the game, is simply undeniably good, throughout balance with fights and environmental situations that can't fail but to make me a bit paranoid and scared.The game, itself, falls short with it's story, however. The backstory behind the main character is explained well as time goes on, but the story itself is nothing but fetch quests and favors where you are rebounded across the entire country just to find out whom Strelok is, whenever the most people have given you is nothing short of, "Oh, I know this other guy who might know him." There is not much motivation to do it after that, and overall, it starts to become tedious within the first few hours of the game as you start to realize that the quests seem silly, as they're nothing but jumbled messes of situations haphazardly thrown together because you're trying to find a man, and even then, that logic goes straight out the window sometimes, so you're left with, "Just do it, because hey, you want to do it!" It is a good mechanic for a free-roaming STALKER game, but not for a man with such an objective in mind, which doesn't even matter until it is pulled up again later on in the game.Anomalies in this game aren't exactly clever, save for a few. The majority of them are simply you getting harmed and then having to use a med kit, which is not much variety between the two, save for that one just stands there, and one pulls you in. The anomalies that go well beyond this, like making you go straight to bleeding badly as soon as you step in them, are good, for they experiment with what they can do, but overall, they just seem a lot like random environmental hazards, which don't really change positions at all.The gunplay is favorable, and, in the right setting, STALKER has monsters and situations that just plain get to you, that really make you shiver in fear. There are flaws in the game, such as stashes being completely devoid of anything until you get the information of the stash itself, but overall, the experience that it makes you go through, as well as the balanced difficulty and unsettling environments, as long as they last before they get bombarded by human enemies out of nowhere, truly make the game what it is.Do I hate this game? Not at all. Despite what I have stated, I could play STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl lots and lots, and still find out new things, which recreates that magical spark that made me love the game whenever I first started playing it.The gameplay is done to such a degree that it actually goes with the very theme of STALKER itself, which completely makes it all the more meaningful once you do discover what it is.What is it, you ask?Well, that's an answer that you'll have to find for yourself. The Zone is full of mysteries, but let it be known that you are like everyone else, improving and trying to live just a little better. Maybe, through the situations you find yourself in, you'll find out what it all teaches us sooner or later.Good hunting, Stalker. I'll be drinking in your honour.

21, 2014
												The only game of this trilogy, this franchise that I am happy to recommend to everybody out there who like post-apocalyptic FPS games. While post-apocalyptic reminds many of us of Fallout 3, Stalker's surroundings are different and instead of the barren lands full of debris you have to imagine a nuclear wasteland. This wasteland is called the Zone and interestingly, the game follows the catastrophe of Chernobyl by adding a twist to the story: here the activities in the power plant did not stop after the incident, in fact, quite the opposite happened which was eventually followed by another explosion. Now, this huge radioactive area is fully of anomalies and mutants and of course stalkers, mercenaries who are obsessed with all this and aim to find all kinds of artifacts that are the results of the catastrophe.While the game was released back in 2007 it should be noted that a mod called COMPLETE is available to enhance everything in the game: it ups the visuals, lowers the amount of bugs and glitches and even adds new features to make the gameplay easier and more exciting. The game offers a free-roaming system: missions can be triggered after speaking with various individuals, other than that you are free to go wherever you want and whenever you want. There are many side missions, too, that lengthen an already long story and as the game offers at least half a dozen endings in the form of rendered cutscenes you have a high replayability value here. One of the downsides for me was that I was not exactly notified that once I start a particular mission there will be no return. With the COMPLETE mod this is now corrected as after completing the story the game puts you back in the Zone and you are free to complete any pending missions you had. Another thing was the difficulty - I have played a lot of FPS games and these I usually complete on hard difficulty settings, too, so I consider myself a veteran but even Stalker was too difficult at times. I believe it is an AI issue as enemies can easily give you headshots from a far distance and there's no room for suprises attacks, either. They are just too good so quick-saving is recommended frequently.Stalker is a classic. It may not be a beautiful game but its gameplay is certainly entertaining and unique. With the COMPLETE mod in place it is an even better experience.

content:
29, 2011
												STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is a difficult game to start, but rewarding to finish. I enjoyed this game more and more as I played; loved it by the end. Fantastic atmosphere.The game is very grim and challenging. It plays mostly like an RPG, because you're taking on missions and learning a story as you go. But there are no levels, no experience points, and no skill tree, so in that regard it's somewhat like an FPS. It's also scary, and resources are scarce, so it bears elements of the survival horror genre, too.The ending is satisfying. Unlike many RPGs that cop out with a boss battle, STALKER gives you answers and a conclusion that makes sense.A few tips if you play. 1) Find and use the "STALKER Complete" mod. It improves the graphics and the English translation, and fixes bugs. 2) It's OK to play on Novice -- you'll die plenty on any setting. 3) Use a game guide. It will help you with the weapons, and keep your story on track. I liked IGN's guide.

content:
r 27, 2014
Note: For these first 1 or 2 paragraphs, it will be a copy/pasted response explaining my lack of game time on Steam. This will be pasted to my other reviews for S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky, and S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat, only changing the games listed here. Starting from the 3rd paragraph and onwards, it will be the actual review.I originally bought the "S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Collection" bundle for about $7.50 on Gamersgate, and back then they only gave me the DRM free(ish) versions of the game. On October 27th 2014, I was going to re-download the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Series, as I had uninstalled it when I went on a massive uninstall spree. Only this time I noticed that GamersGate gave me Steam Keys for the entire collection! So my "XXX hrs on record" will be misleading, as I play a lot of S.T.A.L.K.E.R..Now to the actual review. S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is my favorite S.T.A.L.K.E.R.. I love the entire series, which is set in Ukraine, around the Chernobyl area a few years after the incident with the power plant. I even like Clear Sky, but Shadow of Chernobyl will always be my favorite. You start out in Cordon, an area located inside what's called "The Zone",  talking to Sidorovich. The reason you're talking to him is because near the wreckage of a crashed truck, with only amnesia and a PDA saying "Kill Strelok" to your name. You, known only as the Marked One at this point, ask Sidorovich for help in locating this Strelok, hoping that doing so will help you remember who you are. However, in return, you will need to do a few things for him, though he compensates you in return with information and some sort of good in most cases.However, once you get that first mission from Sidorovich, you're free to do whatever you wish. You can completely ignore his task and go forth to explore the Zone. Granted, there will be a few areas you can't reach without doing the Main Missions, but a good portion of the game is available to you right off the bat.Outside of the main quest line, which is fun and interesting, there are side quests you can find. Now, you won't find as many side quests as you would find in a quality RPG, but there's still a decent amount to find. But other than that, the Zone is a large world for you to explore, finding hidden stashes containing powerful artifacts which give passive boosts, and unique weapons. Hunting mutants and humans alike if you wish. Also, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has a very active mod community. Not as large as some other AAA titles communities, but still very active.Personally, I think this game is a bit dated in the graphics department, and there are some annoying mechanics, like the fast weapon durability loss. I like to use the COMPLETE 2009 Mod, which greatly enhances the graphics and balances the game quite a bit, but still preserves the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. experience nearly perfectly. I say 'nearly' because the Complete mod is the center of many heated neckbeard arguments. The "veterans", which are just a very loud group of people both old and new to the series, claim it makes the game way too easy, and the opposite side arguing the opposite. I've seen this fight so many times with morons on both sides of the argument. The Complete mod DOES give a bit more health to just about everything, but it's not the ultra-mega game changer some make it out to be. It certainly brings the highest difficulty down from "Masochistic" to "Very Difficult", so if you want a Masochistic time, play without the mod. I'd only recommend the mod for Shadow of Chernobyl though. The Clear Sky version isn't very good and absolutely AVOID COMPLETE FOR CALL OF PRIPYAT. The Call of Pripyat version, other than doing little for graphics, puts a save corrupting bug near the end of the game, I'll provide a link to the Complete 2009 ModDB page at the end of this review.Which is pretty much now really. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is an open world FPS game with an incredible atmosphere and amazing gameplay. I recommend it to everyone who likes FPS games in the slightest.S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Complete 2009(2012). It has (2012) on the end because it had a rehaul in 2012. For the Downloads area, look under the title, or above the pretty picture that has "STALKER COMPLETE 2012" on it. Please follow the instructions included with the installer/zip.Afterwards, if you want to play with more mods, or would like to intact with a  S.T.A.L.K.E.R. community that doesn't have the toxicity of the Steam Forums, head on over to the  S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Subreddit on Reddit.com! Clicky clicky.Edit 1: Changed "set in Russia" to "set in Ukraine" after jeeves_bond clarified my mistake. Also, I state that Call of Pripyat COMPLETE introduces a save corrupting bug. That's a small part of it. To be specific, the main issue is that, when it hits, which has a high chance, the bug makes it impossible to move between the last area of the game and the other 2. The only real fix is to load a save from before the final, an second to final area. That's where the save corrupting comes in, as it will sometimes corrupt the saves too.

content:
, 2015
												STALKER Shadow of Chernobyl is my favorite game of all time. There's no way to properly express how fantastic it is. But I'll try I suppose.The game takes place in Chernobyl, as the title suggests, though this Chernobyl is a much more mysterious one. After scientists went and messed around in Chernobyl after the disaster, weird crap started happening. Blowouts, anomalies, artifacts, and nasty warped mutants craving human flesh. The game is a mix between the real life place Chernobyl, obviously, mixed in with world and plot elements from the novel Roadside Picnic (which is my favorite book ever) and the film based on the book, Stalker (which is a great film too). I will never know why they picked that book, Chernobyl, and mutants in one game but one can only think it must've been some divine force that made it happen. The game is a lot like a realistic, Slavic, and overall more terrifying version of Fallout. Not saying that Fallout is bad though.Gameplay is top-notch, the shooting is pretty great and going and finding artifacts can be really tricky. Depending on your alliances, you'll go up against either bandits, different factions, loners, or everyone. The fights are intense and may require many reloads before you figure out how to stump your enemies. This is not an easy game at all, even on the easier difficulties. It's hard as balls and will mess you up hard, you can't go without quicksaving. I'm not good at videogames, so it was a struggle to finish this one, but it was worth it.I can't go talking about a game without talking about it's faults though, no matter how much I adore it. The AI is weird in this one.... it goes from Vash the Stampede level of accuracy to the level of skill you'd expect from a drunk man. The graphics aren't exactly triple-A material either but the atmosphere and the overall visual design makes up for it. STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is an interesting and unique title; there really isn't anything like it. It has its bugs and technical isssues, yes, but that won't stop me from loving truly awesome, scary, intense game. In the words of Number 6™, "There's nothing quite like Russian post-apocalyptic fiction, comrade!"EDIT: I made a video review if you want to check it out.


YouTube™ Video: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl Review 

			Views: 478		

			Review of Shadow of Chernobyl. Gameplay footage from Patrickjet2. Link to the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PBM82j-5Qfs Cheeki breeki, fellow stalker!

content:
ry 11, 2016
												I like others became enamored with this title prior to release.  It was in a class of its own for graphics, and aledged gameplay.I managed to get a CD copy on release, and loved it....Glitches and crashes were common, but somehow seemed normal.  Years later this game has been patched up.  Modifications small and large have been on the scene for years.  This game is totally stable as of 2016, and still totally wonderful.This is one of the best FPS titles I have ever played.  The story is unique, and draws players in.....  The atmosphere of the game is so real, that at times it is best to walk away for a bit and make sure you are not part of it.  Easily a classic in my book.  I Have bought this game at least a half a dozen times on steam.  For myself, for my family and friends.  It is worth it. Years later, I have somehow lost the physical copy....But my pc has not had a CD drive in years....It may very well have been in the drive when it was removed, and unresponsive.  Hopefully someone at the recycling center found that cd and enjoyed it as much as I did.  Buy this game.  It is a FPS survival horror that sets the bar higher than most ever expected it would.  It has some "RPG" elements that add to the experience.  Of the STALKER series, this one is (my opinion) the best.  It has the most depth, and challenges you to balance all parts of your quest throughout an irradiated wasteland.  I find that no matter how often I return to this game, I always feel that I am simply not equipped well enough to survive.  This is normal I think.  It only adds to the fear of the unknown.

content:
18, 2014
												The S.T.A.L.K.E.R series of games is my favorite series of games; Let me preface this review with that statement.Do you like Atmosphere?Do you like a challenging, rewarding experience?Do you like the feeling of helplessness, that edge of adrenaline as something that can snap you like a twig without lifting a finger?If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then this will be a very rewarding game in every aspect of the way. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R series, specifically, Shadow of Chernobyl, is iconic for it's atmosphere so thick it drips out of your screen. The distant sounds of assault rifle fire as you clutch your rusty Kalishnikov to your chest are always terrifying. Is it bandits? Is it a local militia trying to fight off some horrible mutant? You'll always feel vulnerable in the wide, gray fields that make up much of S.T.A.L.K.E.R's landscapes. But don't think running for cover inside will make you safer.. Buildings can be home to traps set by enemies, a bandit camp, or a vicious Bloodsucker's lair. The game mechanics are solid, if abit stiff. You'll never feel cheated if you die; This game is much alike Dark Souls in that regard. However, if you play on any difficulty above Stalker, expect frequent deaths; I reccomend Master, but that's just me. Fortunately, the game features a fairly primitive, if not effective quicksave/load system. Many weapons feel powerful and give feedback; The thunder as you unload a clip from the shiny gun you found on a corpse will always light up the darkness and make you feel alittle less vunerable. Don't take it as a sign of invincibility - Often, you'll be found a few bullets short, gun empty and useless as something with razor-sharp teeth and claws advances on you. However, unless you play a stealthy character, often your knife will be next to useless in combat; As will many of the game's sidearms, unless your primary's run dry. The game also features enemies of the variety of the environment; Anamolies.They're results of the radiation that envelopes the zone, and they're very dangerous; being anything from Static electricty that'll light you up like a christmas tree, to a minature vortex that pulls skin from the bone. All are usually dangerous, but the name of the game in S.T.A.L.K.E.R are the results of Anamolies; Artifacts. They're mysterious objects that grant mystical properties on the human body, from massively increased healing to bullet resistance. Of course, the game isn't flawless. There's many glitches in A.I., but you can't fault a game made in 2007 from a third party company for having some weaknesses. The number one problem with the game is it's voice acting and it's graphics - Even for the time it was released, it wasn't a pretty game. The voice acting is generally pretty atrocious, when it's there - Two of the more famous memes from the game result from this; (Come eehn! Doan juss stah ther!) (GEET OUYT OFF HEER STALKHERR), but overall, that's not the game's strength.Out of the three games, Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky, and Call of Pripyat; I would hesitate in calling this one the best. The other two have far stronger mechanical changes, as well as generally improved voiceacting and graphics.. However, Shadow of Chernobyl will always be the strongest in terms of the feel it gives you. You feel helpless, weak, and scared. Your life is valuable, and the zone can snatch it in an instant. The game doesn't baby you, nor does it hold back. You will die, and you'll love every second if you're a junkie for the things I've mentioned.IF TL:DR, LOOK HERE.Overall..[Starting score of 5 - An average game.]-PROS-Fantastic, immersive atmosphere (+2.5)A unique story and universe (+1.5)A powerful way to improve your character via artifacts (+1)Solid, if stiff mechanics (+1)-CONS-Glitchy, sometimes outright broken A.I. (-1)Horrendous Voice Acting (-1)Often uninventive areas (-1)-TOTAL-  -8.0-A powerful but sometimes unintuitive experience. It'll be memorable for it's unique combat, lore, and mechanics, but occasionally the things that bring down the experience really bring it down. Several times does it show off it's impressive concept of an apocalyptic world, but once or twice it falls short. If you're a fan of a deep, immersive game that'll take you a week or more to complete simply from just how difficult it can be, then this game's your one-trick pony. If not, you might be able to get some enjoyment from the pure russian that this game is. If not, then it likely isn't your sort of game.

content:
y 24
												This is a beautifully atmospheric game with a very believable and detailed world. The gunplay is relentless, the inaccuracy of your weapons make you feel helpless at the start but you feel a great sense of progression the more you get through the game and get better weapons that are more reliable and accurate. I found the enemy ai to be pretty decent, they constantly try to flank you and push your position but also trying to keep a distance from you at times peeking from cover while crouched. The story has some great ideas and twists put into it but the storytelling itself and the way the story is being presented is not very compelling or interesting, but it doesn’t really feel like the story was the main focus for the developers, the game feels more focused on the world building than anything else. Because the developers chose to make the weapons very inaccurate there can be frustrating moments in the game where you just can’t hit the enemy even at close range when your aiming down your sights right on the enemies head with a pistol. This is the type of game where there is a lot of trail and error and quite a bit of save scumming especially in the first few hours because you are so weak. For about the first 4 hours of the game I found myself quick saving constantly almost to the point where I quick saved every time I killed 1 or 2 enemies because I felt like I really needed to the highest difficulty and that can get pretty annoying. I did enjoy fighting some of the unique creatures the game has to offer and going through those bunkers and labs is very atmospheric, creepy and well done. I really liked the survival aspect of the game too like how you have to eat food so you don’t get hungry or managing your supplies carefully because you do have a pretty small weight limit. I played through the game vanilla without any mods and I thought it was great, good mods may enhance the experience but it’s definitely not required.8/10 (Great)

												Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl is a highly enjoyable game with a lot of realism (I died about 15 times in the opening quest)the combat and survival aspects provide an enjoyable and difficult experience, unlike many games on the market you will not be likely to feel very powerful in Stalker, if your shot at point blank range with a shotgun you will definately die no questions asked, where this game suffers is mainly in problems due to age while it does feature an open world that world is segmented into pieces, their still expansive but don't expect giant areas.The second place this game has its shortfalls are simply graphical, this is simply because of the age of the game and the graphical limitations of the time, a HD remake would definately be in order.Overall if your not fanatical about Graphical quality or slightly older game mechanics, Shadow of Chernobyl provides a realistic enjoyable and throughly enjoyable open world, survival shooter experience.

												Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl is a highly enjoyable game with a lot of realism (I died about 15 times in the opening quest)the combat and survival aspects provide an enjoyable and difficult experience, unlike many games on the market you will not be likely to feel very powerful in Stalker, if your shot at point blank range with a shotgun you will definately die no questions asked, where this game suffers is mainly in problems due to age while it does feature an open world that world is segmented into pieces, their still expansive but don't expect giant areas.The second place this game has its shortfalls are simply graphical, this is simply because of the age of the game and the graphical limitations of the time, a HD remake would definately be in order.Overall if your not fanatical about Graphical quality or slightly older game mechanics, Shadow of Chernobyl provides a realistic enjoyable and throughly enjoyable open world, survival shooter experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2012
												One of the best shooters I've ever played. Can be frustrating due to poor translation and a confusing system of timed side-quests which automatically assign and fail regularly. Learning to ignore these is a leap of faith necessary to enjoy the game.Once you're past its failings, STALKER is pure and often terrifying fun. Lots of space to roam, a solid item system, believable and intricate interiors. Friendly wanderers, roaming bandits; real choice in weapons & armor rather than your usual planned-out, linear upgrades.For the frustrated, there are mods out there which fix the translation, alter NPC behavior, permit equipment repair, and so on. If you forgo these, be advised that the first two areas are extremely difficult due to your weak equipment, so avoiding combat there is usually the smart move. There will be plenty of time for payback later.All in all, a flawed but irreplaceable classic which is not for everyone, but which everyone should try.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 24
												This is a beautifully atmospheric game with a very believable and detailed world. The gunplay is relentless, the inaccuracy of your weapons make you feel helpless at the start but you feel a great sense of progression the more you get through the game and get better weapons that are more reliable and accurate. I found the enemy ai to be pretty decent, they constantly try to flank you and push your position but also trying to keep a distance from you at times peeking from cover while crouched. The story has some great ideas and twists put into it but the storytelling itself and the way the story is being presented is not very compelling or interesting, but it doesn’t really feel like the story was the main focus for the developers, the game feels more focused on the world building than anything else. Because the developers chose to make the weapons very inaccurate there can be frustrating moments in the game where you just can’t hit the enemy even at close range when your aiming down your sights right on the enemies head with a pistol. This is the type of game where there is a lot of trail and error and quite a bit of save scumming especially in the first few hours because you are so weak. For about the first 4 hours of the game I found myself quick saving constantly almost to the point where I quick saved every time I killed 1 or 2 enemies because I felt like I really needed to the highest difficulty and that can get pretty annoying. I did enjoy fighting some of the unique creatures the game has to offer and going through those bunkers and labs is very atmospheric, creepy and well done. I really liked the survival aspect of the game too like how you have to eat food so you don’t get hungry or managing your supplies carefully because you do have a pretty small weight limit. I played through the game vanilla without any mods and I thought it was great, good mods may enhance the experience but it’s definitely not required.8/10 (Great)

content:
ry 11, 2016
												I like others became enamored with this title prior to release.  It was in a class of its own for graphics, and aledged gameplay.I managed to get a CD copy on release, and loved it....Glitches and crashes were common, but somehow seemed normal.  Years later this game has been patched up.  Modifications small and large have been on the scene for years.  This game is totally stable as of 2016, and still totally wonderful.This is one of the best FPS titles I have ever played.  The story is unique, and draws players in.....  The atmosphere of the game is so real, that at times it is best to walk away for a bit and make sure you are not part of it.  Easily a classic in my book.  I Have bought this game at least a half a dozen times on steam.  For myself, for my family and friends.  It is worth it. Years later, I have somehow lost the physical copy....But my pc has not had a CD drive in years....It may very well have been in the drive when it was removed, and unresponsive.  Hopefully someone at the recycling center found that cd and enjoyed it as much as I did.  Buy this game.  It is a FPS survival horror that sets the bar higher than most ever expected it would.  It has some "RPG" elements that add to the experience.  Of the STALKER series, this one is (my opinion) the best.  It has the most depth, and challenges you to balance all parts of your quest throughout an irradiated wasteland.  I find that no matter how often I return to this game, I always feel that I am simply not equipped well enough to survive.  This is normal I think.  It only adds to the fear of the unknown.

content:
, 2014
												STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is, at its core, a unique, immersive shooter with a phenomenal AI.The gunplay is solid with plenty of weapon, ammo, and armor variety, and the game's open world and survival-oriented mechanics (hunger, radiation poisoning, bleeding, and a few others) set it apart from its peers and work to bring the Zone to life. One of its crowning features is the ALife (Artificial Life) system, which attempts to simulate a sort of persistent ecosystem throughout the Zone with roving, hierachical packs of mutants and wandering (or occasionally raiding) Stalkers, bandits, and soldiers. The graphics, while somewhat dated, are by no means ugly, and can be easily improved with mods.SoC is somewhat hampered by a plethora of bugs and sometimes frustrating design choices (irreversible weapon/armor decay) along with an overall weak plot and even weaker endgame. The game does, however, feature multiple endings, but the story isn't engaging enough for them to be particularly impactful. The world itself is still engaging and allows the player to very much craft their own stories, though it lacks any interactive vignettes such a setting would be conducive to. A personal gripe, I admit, but the Zone lacks in characters what it makes up for in atmosphere. While any mechanical issues can typically be modded away, the narrative can't really be improved upon.Word of warning - much of the ambient dialogue is in Russian, which, while immersive, sort of hampers interaction with any of the inhabitants. This is not as prevalent in the later titles, especially not in Call of Pripyat.

												STALKER SOC é um survival FPS open world muito bom, dificil e cheio de defeitos.Mesmo tendo gerenciamento de inventário e side quests, ele não tem nada de RPG - ele é mais um FarCry 2 do que Deus Ex HR.A história é interessante e surpreende um pouco. Contem três finais, bem diferentes e muito bons.A ambientação, atmosfera e trilha sonora são sensacionais.The Zone é um lugar que você precisa conhecer e explorar.As side quests são fracas e repetitivas, e o trading é ridiculo.As facções diferentes praticamente não fazem diferença no jogo.O gunplay é um pouco esquisito e alguns inimigos são simplesmente bullet sponges.Se for jogar pela primeira vez, não use MODs como Complete, Lost Alpha, Autumn Aurora pois eles alteram demais o jogo. Jogue o mais vanilla possivel, com pequenos MODs que só consertam bugs e melhoram a atmosfera como ZRP, Absolute Nature, AtmosFear, etc.Dou nota 8/10, recomendo, e com certeza está na minha lista Top 10.E 'get out of here, Stalker'!

content:
er 23, 2015
												Stalker has been considered by many a post-apocalyptic first person shooter game. But it isn't, your in a Cordon zone of the Chernobyl area that has been abandon since April of 1986 due to NPP4 catastrophic failure rendering the environment hazardous to live in. Yes, the place dose exists for real, all locations are based on real locations in the real zone. Life is still going on everyday for the people out side of the zone. The Stalker game series is inspired off the book "Roadside Picnic", which is a short science fiction novel written by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky in 1971. More information on this book is available on a wiki, and the book is also available in English now.  The game is a open world exploration as well as mission directive, Remember that.Shadow Of Chernobyl is the first release of the stalker game series, not only is it less buggy, but the most mod friendly. I been in this zone since the first release of the dvd 1.0 in 2007. Back when modders were just starting out the great mega big mods that change the game story such as AMK, Inferno, Oblivion Lost, and Priboy came along pioneering the way to the mods of today. Matter in fact, some of the modders works can be found even in Clear Sky's dbase files like AMK is listed, some of the team even has scripts in it. Here your in the Cordon off Zone in which has become a prison. You can get in, but you can't get out. There is trading with traders, and different factions that may or may not care for you. Many dangerous anomalies to contend with, and artifact to collect and sell for money. Have to watch out for the areas that are radioactive still. One of the things to remember is question everyone and trust no one. Being skeptical with a gut feeling at times is better than a fire fight, When in this game it is important. It also in this game you have 3 alternate ending, pending on how or what you do will decide the end of your fate.. It works on win7 64 bit, you may want to check in the forums. There has been complaints pending Operating systems causing issues with the game. The stalker community out of many I have seen is the most helpful there. It seems every stalker dose what they can to help you. And a good community like that is a nice thing to have.

content:
3, 2016
												Yes, Stalker SoC is more than worth a buy. The feelings of dread and desperation as you traverse the insecure, almost-open-world will make you yearn for more while simultaneously hopping for it to stop.It’s Chernobyl. Because, somewhere, it had to be. Be glad it’s here though! Besides the technical issues that you may or may not experience at the hands of SoC, this is a damn fine game that mixes open levels, faction warfare as well as dark, claustrophobic maps. So well is the mixture that you will only take breaks to watch My Little Pony or Adventure Time episodes, in order to calm down a bit.That’s not to say that it’s all horror, but the horror parts are intense, with mutants invisible, sneaky or able to take control from you altogether. The remaining parts are equal in intensity, with stumbling over faction warfare, random anomalies or stalkers (a.k.a. wanderers) with whom you can talk for the info or kill for the loot. The world around you is also alive. Nights will see an intensity in animal and mutant activity, while daylight will witness packs of hounds hunting, wild boars migrating from one part of the (large) map to another and so forth. You will also constantly encounter random patrols or couriers, from different factions, the faction itself depending on the level you are in. But, like I originally said, the game is riddled with bugs. Some from the get-go, some due to the game being out of date. Of course, a title of this caliber will always have a smart fan-base covering it's needs, and there are excellent mods out there, combining graphics upgrades, tweaks and bug fixes all in one.The only reason I would not recommend getting this is if you already own Call of Pripyat (the 3rd game in the series, that improved much on the formula). If not, SoC is a serious contender to CoP, but ultimately, if you like one, you will want to play both. I recommend starting with this.

content:
ry 20, 2015
												STALKER is an example of a game that has numerous flaws, and yet manages to be amazing.  In fact, despite its bugs, unfinished and missing content, janky world etc. has managed to find a spot in my top 10 most beloved games of all time.  Not only that, it is the one game that has sold me on the concept of a survival game.  The Zone is a trecherous, scary place that is caked in so much atmopshere that it's hard not to feel as though every step you take is one step closer to your own untimely demise, and nothing is as satisfying as making it out of a rough encounter without bleeding to death or barely escaping an irradiated area after you realized you didn't pack enough anti-rads.  You are NEVER safe in this game.  Ever.  Admittedly Shadow of Chernobyl is the most linear of the three STALKER games, but honestly each one is cheap enough that you should just get all 3.  If you want a more open world, then play Clear Sky or even better Call of Pripyat.  But Shadow fo Chernobyl is still a gripping experience and a great starting point for this wonderful, creepy world - and there are lots of mods out there worth checking out, as well as the excellent standalone game STALKER: Lost Alpha which seeks to recreate STALKER based on its original design document and the many features that were cut during its lengthy 6 year development time.  Definitely check this one out.

content:
, 2016
												There it is. I wanted to play S.T.A.L.K.E.R. since it's release after i have read an article on it. Now after 32h of game i have completed the story mode, what can i say? This game is definetly not for every one. It's specific atmosphere is somewhat depressing, well, there should not be any surprise on this as ti is a part of game.My first impression when i started to play was that camera movement is kind of weird, but after a while i got used to it. Next weird thing was shooting mechanism, to desctibe it in one sentence: "I shoot the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the head and then he kiled me". I have wrote about atmosphere if the game, but there is more to it. If i would have to choose what genre this game is i would say something between survival horror, sneaking game and FPS. Game is not scary all the time, but there are some locations that can give you a goosebumps, like lab x-16 or x-18, or any other location, where you have to use a flashlight and creepy noises are all around.Nice thing in game was possibity to pick up gun from your fallen enemies. During gameplay i didn't have to buy any of primary weapon, all of them can be droped by mobs, however some of them are quite rare, like Gaus Gun. I have picked it up on very end of the game in Chernobyl NPP sarkophagus.Another thing that i liked was posibility to sneak on almost every enemy including mutants, sometimes i is quite handy, that you can try to kill a baddie with a single shot (ammo conservation is important cause you don't want to be left with a knife, trust me ;)Gameplay of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. in  overall was nice, after i got used to it, despite some frustrating moments, of F7, F7, F7, F7 ;). This is another thing that you should remember of: quick save whenever you are sure you are safe. If you forget to save, you can lost your progress very easily as on every stage of game almost every enemy can kill you fast.For me this is a nice game and i don't feel disappointed, now it is time for second part :)I would recommend this game to everybody who is not affraid of exploring radiated teritorries of Chernobyl outskirts and want to have their whish granted :)TIP: In game you have to run a long distances, at the beginning use energy drinks, later equip yourself with artifact Flash x2 or Moonlight x2 or combination of those two. They will give you infinite stamina when you are not too loaded and if you walk because you run out, your stamina will regenerate.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Best atmosphere of any video game possibly ever.. Cringeworthy AI/Combat bullet dmg however.(The amazing atmosphere, guns, sounds, mutants, visuals of this game outweight the poor AI cons a million to one)I am not mad or angry writing this review. I am perfectly calm. Not butthurt. I love that stalker exists and technically speaking is one of the most impressive fps game engines i've ever experienced. I am still enjoying the game right now actually. I know this will hurt your feelings bringing up some negatives but its what i observe from playing the game again in 20161.Terrible AI. Sadly this is true.-Sometimes enemies will tactically walk into the room.. backwards??-you can walk up to a bandit camp with a non-silenced rifle, shoot one of the three patrol guards in the head.. watch him drop.. then just watch his friends walk around his dead body like nothing happened. -You shoot a guard, watch him flinch, see the blood spatter, and he will just continue patrolling without becoming alarmed or doing anything differently-Enemies do not respond to sounds or flashlights, they just automatically face you when you come within 15ft of them (regardless if you are sneaking or not)Once you get a little way into the game, It takes about 1-2 headshot to kill, or... 30-70 body shots. I wish i was being sarcastic. How could a game with so much realism ingrained into the atmosphere possibly have such an insultingly unrealistic bullet damage system? It takes smart people to make such a realistic engaging atmosphere like this. So i am surprised that they all collectively agreed on this arcade-like bullet damage system. I just wish it was more realistic (3-5 body shots for medium armor enemies, 7 body shots for heavy armor enemies)**UPDATE** The above statement needs to be re-visited, yes it does take a lot of shots to kill an enemy.. But after playing for many more hours i have determined that this game is set up more like an RPG than a traditional FPS. It makes sense because the developers want you to come across better geared enemies as you go deeper through the game. Although it does feel silly having to shoot an enemy with 70 body shots at times. So...Continuing with the horrors of AI. They rarely respond to gunshot sounds, if they do its completely incorrect and they walk to the wrong locationIf you see an enemy in a window and fire at him, you would expect him to look out the window and return fire.. But no. The AI just gets confused, walks around in that room for a bit then crouches and aims at a wall until you walk upstairs and kill him as he stares at the wall.If you are behind a big 6 inch steel wall or something, enemies will just shoot at the wall till the end of timeThe game does have a lot of positive things too however, the graphics are top notch, the sounds are FLAWLESS, the controls and user interface is very fitting for the atmosphere..

But after playing for many more hours i have determined that this game is set up more like an RPG than a traditional FPS. It makes sense because the developers want you to come across better geared enemies as you go deeper through the game. Although it does feel silly having to shoot an enemy with 70 body shots at times. So...Continuing with the horrors of AI. They rarely respond to gunshot sounds, if they do its completely incorrect and they walk to the wrong locationIf you see an enemy in a window and fire at him, you would expect him to look out the window and return fire.. But no. The AI just gets confused, walks around in that room for a bit then crouches and aims at a wall until you walk upstairs and kill him as he stares at the wall.If you are behind a big 6 inch steel wall or something, enemies will just shoot at the wall till the end of timeThe game does have a lot of positive things too however, the graphics are top notch, the sounds are FLAWLESS, the controls and user interface is very fitting for the atmosphere..

content:
, 2016
												There it is. I wanted to play S.T.A.L.K.E.R. since it's release after i have read an article on it. Now after 32h of game i have completed the story mode, what can i say? This game is definetly not for every one. It's specific atmosphere is somewhat depressing, well, there should not be any surprise on this as ti is a part of game.My first impression when i started to play was that camera movement is kind of weird, but after a while i got used to it. Next weird thing was shooting mechanism, to desctibe it in one sentence: "I shoot the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the head and then he kiled me". I have wrote about atmosphere if the game, but there is more to it. If i would have to choose what genre this game is i would say something between survival horror, sneaking game and FPS. Game is not scary all the time, but there are some locations that can give you a goosebumps, like lab x-16 or x-18, or any other location, where you have to use a flashlight and creepy noises are all around.Nice thing in game was possibity to pick up gun from your fallen enemies. During gameplay i didn't have to buy any of primary weapon, all of them can be droped by mobs, however some of them are quite rare, like Gaus Gun. I have picked it up on very end of the game in Chernobyl NPP sarkophagus.Another thing that i liked was posibility to sneak on almost every enemy including mutants, sometimes i is quite handy, that you can try to kill a baddie with a single shot (ammo conservation is important cause you don't want to be left with a knife, trust me ;)Gameplay of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. in  overall was nice, after i got used to it, despite some frustrating moments, of F7, F7, F7, F7 ;). This is another thing that you should remember of: quick save whenever you are sure you are safe. If you forget to save, you can lost your progress very easily as on every stage of game almost every enemy can kill you fast.For me this is a nice game and i don't feel disappointed, now it is time for second part :)I would recommend this game to everybody who is not affraid of exploring radiated teritorries of Chernobyl outskirts and want to have their whish granted :)TIP: In game you have to run a long distances, at the beginning use energy drinks, later equip yourself with artifact Flash x2 or Moonlight x2 or combination of those two. They will give you infinite stamina when you are not too loaded and if you walk because you run out, your stamina will regenerate.

ber 21, 2016
												First thing: tried in windows 7 32bit game was crashing every 5 minutes, so i had to install in a computer with windows xp where the game never crashed one single time.I am a purist, so i like to play games as they are released by the original developers, for me, installing any MOD is the same as using cheats and i hate cheats too, so i've played this game without any mod and my review is based on that.So, let me start with this, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a GREAT game, really, the ambientation is fantastic and so are the graphic and music, i would have given this game without problem a score of 80 and above but, i really could not, because of too many flaws.A part the fact the game is full of many mini bugs, but nothing you can't handle with, when you start for the first time, you'll face an insane level of difficuly that in other games of this kind i rarely experienced....you shoot in the face for 3 times a bandit with a gun and he survive and shoot you back...this can't be, but in this game this will happens...Moving, by feet, from one point of the map to other take ages, a problem that in other 2 Stalker games was solved...One of the most annoying things was that you can NOT repair your weapons or your armors, you must find a new one once some of your gears get damaged too much, again, a problem solved in other 2 Stalkers...The game is overall very hard but the final part is something ridiculously hard, evenn too much, altough, maybe, was one of the best final fights i did among all 3 Stalker games...There are radiations everywhere :-)So, in conclusion, the game is very well made, it's good, but is very far from perfection, i would recommend it only to hardcore gamers, others are adviced...My Final Score is 70 /100

r 21, 2013
												i am a HUGE fan of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games(well..maybe not Clear Sky but it had some good things which were improved in Call of Pripyat),when i first saw the screenshots of Shadow of Chernobyl back in 2005-2006 i knew deep within it was a game i would dig,and i did...more than i actually thought i would,i am in love with this game,it's setting is amazing and original,especially for it's time and because ever since i heard about the accident back in 1986 i was interested in it and seeing a FPS made in it without it being "yeah you shoot dudes in Pripyat to save some dude you don't care about" and more like "you have to survive and scrape your ♥♥♥♥ together and if you don't look out you will be murdered..gruesomely" was like a dream come true,the series' strongest point is by far the amazingly gloomy atmosphere,(the voice acting sucks though,first thing you have to do is download the original,Russian soundfiles and put them into the game,it makes the game 10x better) and the fact in every game you start out with the most shity equipment(that being the Makarov pistol) it takes skill to actually be good at the game,and when you take down that bandit camp near the millitairy checkpoint in the Cordon in SoC for the first time on your own with just a pistol and if you are lucky a sawed off shotgun,you feel great(and even get rewarded with usefull stuff if you do it that way!) the series have loads of original ideas,like the concept of anomalies and them being lethal if you don't have good equipment,the sometimes extreme background radiation also really adds to the setting of the place(that being the 30 square kilometer Zone in which the fallout was the heaviest) and the wide variety of weapons,armors and artifacts(being little trinkets you can sell for good cash and provide boons like extra resistance against bites and bleeding and extended endureance so that can sprint longer) the music is ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic,especially in the later levels,and the main menu theme is depressing and actually really gloomy aswell,which fits the series' overall atmosphere all in all i love the series,especially the first game and the fact that to this day,there is a thriving modding community for SoC is a reason for me to go back from time to time and experience the horrors of the Zone once more well,what are you waiting for? buy the game already and good hunting Stalker!

												Don't mind hour count. Had this as a physical copy, in the first place, way before Steam.This game is the pinnacle of post apocalyptic games. Pure survival. Constantly low ammo, low medicines, broken armour and weapons, and a ♥♥♥♥ ton of spooky enemies everywhere. You can also perish for not eating or drinking, not to mention radiation. And not to mention gravitational/eletromagnetic anomalies you'll stumble into while running for your life, or searching for radioactive artifacts, that will either way kill you hopelessly. Everytime you leave your safe haven to start a quest, it feels like a true adventure... and you're never sure you'll be back in one piece on the first try. Most of the time, you won't. Be ready to cry, to yell, to pray, to hunt down bandits in the darkness, to spray your last AK magazine towards invisible tentacle-faced abominations in order to desperately try to save your life, to drink ♥♥♥♥♥ons of vodka, and most importantly, to cheeki breeki.10/10

content:
, 2015
												Where do I start with this game? I've played through it twice and am currently on my third play through after beating the trilogy a few years ago. I downloaded the STALKER Complete 2009 mod which I hoped would refresh the game without introducing stupid gameplay imbalances. I was right. It's still one of the greatest and most demanding open-world first person role playing games out there. And I think I would be justified in saying that it on its own rivals the AAA competitors like Fallout 3 or New Vegas. It's just that good.It plays really nicely, and because it's such an old game it runs smoothly with high anti-aliasing and high frame rates. As a core game you are sort of thrown into the combat with little preparation, but it doesn't take an experienced shooter-player to realize that you need to duck and cover. Leaning is super important, and enemies like to shoot when you move forcing you to play patiently and not go commando. That being said, once you get the formula down, you just sit and pop enemies when they poke their heads out. Pretty standard. The real challenge is fighting monsters which will scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of you and really put your twitch-shooter skills to the test. Interacting with friendlies and setting out on quests is easy enough, but oftentimes the quests will end in ways you don't expect due to the uncertain nature of everything occurring in the game-world. You plan an ambush with some buddies and only you made it out? That's your fault but you gotta move on.The Complete 2009 mod really polishes off the game nicely. Textures are still pretty sharp, and the world is brimming with anomalies and enemies. You really notice the subtle touches like rain pouring outside and forcing friendlies to huddle inside next to barrel stoves. The sound is good but definitely dated. I really like having to use directional sound to orient myself and in a game like this that feature really stands out. The day-night cycles are intense and I found myself sleeping through the nights so as to have a daylight advantage in combat.The story is super intriguing and really enhanced by the dark and radioactive atmosphere. Everything could be dangerous and you gotta be on your game if you want to make it out alive. What's awesome is that you can play this game multiple times and get fairly different experiences in terms of the narrative and your late-game character's attributes. Some people go full ecologist and collect anomalies to enhance their character. Some seek the best guns ever. Some have the best armor. It's all pretty standard for the genre, but it is executed well and provides a player with a large range of choices to make throughout the story.Addendum: So I beat it after reloading a quick save every 15 minutes because holy ♥♥♥♥ the monolith stalkers really throw everything in the game at you including gunships, mutants, armor piercing ammunition, and their sheer numbers (I killed maybe 40 in the last part of the game?). I don't want to spoil the ending so I won't, but I will address the "incoherence" some people claim the game's story is guilty of. I am pretty sure that the curators that made that claim were either skipping through all the dialogue, or just refuse to acknowledge that a team of devs outside of the United States can make a compelling, unique, and deeply original story. Or maybe game journalists are all ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I think that's most likely.This game is not appealing to the same crowds that find the Fallout or Metro games appealing, and I think that the reason for that is in the fantasies and idealized situations the game constructs for the player. It really does give you the sensation of being inna woods with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ soviet guns that jam all the time fighting hostile creatures and violently entrepreneurial bandits. You also get the neat sensation of collecting artifacts for science, and doing so under the constant oppression of the military and rival paramilitary factions that seemingly have no scientific aims. While in this debut title, there is no explicit faction-joining for the player, you do participate and witness the war for these radioactive artifacts, and it absolutely informs your player-choices that do in fact yield wildly different endings to the game--bad endings if you're a lazy and stupid player that doesn't read dialogue. I have beaten this game 3 times now I think? I'll never be able to eat ♥♥♥♥♥♥ spam knock-offs again without thinking about my misadventures in the zone scrounging for artifacts, assassinating corrupt military commanders and bandits, and drinking a dozen handles of vodka to make the radiation sickness go away. If you're intrigued play it and get hooked and maybe you'll pick up Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat which I'll review at some point.

content:
er 27, 2011
												This game has had a pretty notorious reputation not long after it was announced in the early 2000's. It underwent numerous different designs, names, and builds before finally getting released in late 2007. Even then, some felt that the game was still a rushed beta, and honestly it was. It wasn't until several patches that the game was decently stable. However to many people, the game's now-trademark atmosphere, brutal gameplay and unforgiving gameplay environment were enough to leave the game permanently ingrained in gamer's minds across the globe.Flash forward to 2013, and this game still has a devoted modding community who are regularly working on and releasing ambitious new total conversions, weapon packs, gameplay tweaks and even restorations of previously-cut content. This game must be experienced first-hand. Even the base 2007 game is still good today, though the game truly shines once one ventures out and starts downloading various mods that make the game several orders of magnitude better. This reviewer here prefers 'Oblivion Lost 2.2', which is based on a previous version of the game -- it restores many gameplay concepts and features that were left out for reasons unknown. It adds in more weapons, more suits, creatures, improved graphics, smoother performance, vehicles, and even free-play. It also adds in complete A-Life, which is unlocked after a player beats the game with the best ending, where every STALKER in the Zone begins to operately totally freely, which can open up many unique scenarios which no two players will experience the same. The story is fairly gripping, though players expecting constant cutscenes and characters who never shut up will be disappointed. The story is told primarily through notes left in PDA's and some interactions with other humans face-to-face, though the few cutscenes there are do a wonderful job of contributing to the haunting atmosphere the game promotes. The gameplay is tough and unforgiving -- this game isn't for the noobs out there. You won't be charging at enemies doing 1080-degree backflips while going for no-scopes here. You have to pick your shots and battles carefully. Sometimes it's better to flee than fight, or use stealth to completely dodge enemies (or ambush them to take their loot!) STALKER in essence is an FPSRPG. You've got the traditional first-person shooter gameplay, combined with an inventory system, a stats system for both weapons and equipment, the latter of which directly affects the player's endurance and performance, quests, NPC's to interact with, and a fully dynamic open world that is constantly alive. The harsh environment, dubbed "The Zone", is as much a challenge as the humans and mutants you must deal with on a daily basis. Due to the events which took place prior to the game, the Zone has changed drastically, and there are mutant creatures and "anomalies" scattered everywhere. Careless players will go on raids without enough equipment, or foolishly walk through dark areas without watching their step, only to find themselves getting insta-gibbed by an anomaly. The A.I. is nothing to snicker at either, and they get even tougher if you play with most mods. Don't be surprised to be in a firefight with someone, only to lose track of them and then have them sneak up behind you and offload half a magazine into the back of your skull. Shadow of Chernobyl also boasts a pretty barebones multiplayer component, but in all honesty, this pales in comparison to the single-player experience, which is a shame. It can be fun for a little while, but several gameplay decisions quickly make it evident that it's easy to become overpowered against other players, making the experience very un-STALKER like. All in all, this game is worth the asking price, even years later. Buy this damned game, it's worth it.

content:
, 2016
												A one of a kind horror/shooter with a compelling plot, fantastic array of weapons and equipment, an immersive world, and an interesting array of factions and personalities. I recommend this particularly to fans of Metro 2033/Last Light as a more challenging and atmospheric alternative, despite being a good few years old, the game has aged well and (as far as I have experienced.) Runs smoothly; it contains a very nice inventory system also. The plot follows a Russian 'S.T.A.L.K.E.R' who has come to the zone to scavenge for artifacts after a fictional second explosion at the Chernobyl reactor, but suffers amnesia. The rest picks up from there. Despite the stellar experience, I do find the game is plagued by steep difficulty curves, an unusable stealth mechanic (the HUD has a sound metre but as far as I know, stealth isn't possible unless the enemy is sleeping.) And I found a lot of the areas looking a little too similar to one another, however, this doesn't tarnish this true gem of modern times.10/10 Would cheeki breeki again.

content:
er 19, 2013
												Every now and then a game which is one-of-a-kind and offers a completely unforgettable experience is made. This is one of those games. If you haven't tried S.T.A.L.K.E.R. before then now is the time. This FPS/RPG provides a realistic experience through proper weapon and damage mechanics and a special "A-Life" AI engine which allows The Zone to continue living and changing even when the player isn't there. This game does not provide an easy start for newcomers, dropping you into the harsh and desolate Zone with nothing but a jacket and a pistol. But it will reward players who continue onward using common sense and quick judgement to overcome the myriad of obstacles on their journey to the Center of The Zone. If you haven't tried this game, try it. But don't try for 5 minutes and then give up because it's "too hard". Give it a couple of hours and in those hours think to yourself "If I was actually in The Zone, what would I do?"Good hunting S.T.A.L.K.E.R. See you in The Zone.

content:
er 27, 2011
												This game has had a pretty notorious reputation not long after it was announced in the early 2000's. It underwent numerous different designs, names, and builds before finally getting released in late 2007. Even then, some felt that the game was still a rushed beta, and honestly it was. It wasn't until several patches that the game was decently stable. However to many people, the game's now-trademark atmosphere, brutal gameplay and unforgiving gameplay environment were enough to leave the game permanently ingrained in gamer's minds across the globe.Flash forward to 2013, and this game still has a devoted modding community who are regularly working on and releasing ambitious new total conversions, weapon packs, gameplay tweaks and even restorations of previously-cut content. This game must be experienced first-hand. Even the base 2007 game is still good today, though the game truly shines once one ventures out and starts downloading various mods that make the game several orders of magnitude better. This reviewer here prefers 'Oblivion Lost 2.2', which is based on a previous version of the game -- it restores many gameplay concepts and features that were left out for reasons unknown. It adds in more weapons, more suits, creatures, improved graphics, smoother performance, vehicles, and even free-play. It also adds in complete A-Life, which is unlocked after a player beats the game with the best ending, where every STALKER in the Zone begins to operately totally freely, which can open up many unique scenarios which no two players will experience the same. The story is fairly gripping, though players expecting constant cutscenes and characters who never shut up will be disappointed. The story is told primarily through notes left in PDA's and some interactions with other humans face-to-face, though the few cutscenes there are do a wonderful job of contributing to the haunting atmosphere the game promotes. The gameplay is tough and unforgiving -- this game isn't for the noobs out there. You won't be charging at enemies doing 1080-degree backflips while going for no-scopes here. You have to pick your shots and battles carefully. Sometimes it's better to flee than fight, or use stealth to completely dodge enemies (or ambush them to take their loot!) STALKER in essence is an FPSRPG. You've got the traditional first-person shooter gameplay, combined with an inventory system, a stats system for both weapons and equipment, the latter of which directly affects the player's endurance and performance, quests, NPC's to interact with, and a fully dynamic open world that is constantly alive. The harsh environment, dubbed "The Zone", is as much a challenge as the humans and mutants you must deal with on a daily basis. Due to the events which took place prior to the game, the Zone has changed drastically, and there are mutant creatures and "anomalies" scattered everywhere. Careless players will go on raids without enough equipment, or foolishly walk through dark areas without watching their step, only to find themselves getting insta-gibbed by an anomaly. The A.I. is nothing to snicker at either, and they get even tougher if you play with most mods. Don't be surprised to be in a firefight with someone, only to lose track of them and then have them sneak up behind you and offload half a magazine into the back of your skull. Shadow of Chernobyl also boasts a pretty barebones multiplayer component, but in all honesty, this pales in comparison to the single-player experience, which is a shame. It can be fun for a little while, but several gameplay decisions quickly make it evident that it's easy to become overpowered against other players, making the experience very un-STALKER like. All in all, this game is worth the asking price, even years later. Buy this damned game, it's worth it.

content:
er 3, 2015
												The start of the bleak ex-bloc survival shooter. STALKER SoC is an example of a systems-heavy open world FPS, that does an amazing job of demonstrating the broader potential within the genre. The mix of exploration, survival, hostile environment, and warring factions, makes for a much more compelling setting than any standard military or tactical shooter. The story of SoC is particularly strong, despite leaning on an amnesiac opening, and with multiple endings, you'll at least want to keep a few save files on hand. Travel and exploration are both dangerous and rewarding. Managing your inventory is a challenge, requiring mastery in itself. If you go into Stalker expecting to be an RPG-style pack mule, you'll be disappointed. For all that it does so well, and the ways in which it innovates, I don't feel that the game as released is truly "complete". While I'd recommend playing it in vanilla, for your first run through (and you'll probably want a second), I can't recommend "Oblivion Lost" too highly, when it comes to revisiting the game. Previously empty areas of the map are filled, new creatures introduced, and others taken to a superior state. If you ever wondered how the "Psuedodog" got its name, you'll figure that out pretty quick, in a playthrough of Oblivion Lost. If you're a fan of the FPS genre, this is a must for you to experience. The Zone is not for the feint of heart, but it is a pivotal stop for FPS fans.

content:
, 2013
												Let's just say I love this game, #1 fav, always. If you have never heard of this game, then you're in for a treat. This game has got an enjoyable and replayable story, not to mention some of the mods for this game (StalkerSoup, Oblivion Lost, AMK, Doom's Mod Merge being my favorites). If you are just starting out on this game, play it through in vanilla on first playthrough (just a warning it.. can be sometimes buggy and unpredictable in vanilla, from my experience anyway) and once you've completed the game, I would recommend downloading a mod. It can be any mod of your choice (obviously) but I would highly recommend something like AMK or Oblivion Lost, they're both fairly simplistic, both add new features but nothing too big. They also add things like new weapons, armour and what not, don't worry, it doesn't dumb the game down like that awful excuse for a mod Stalker Complete, it's still a challenge, so never fear! As for StalkerSoup, it is difficult I would only recommend this to experienced STALKER players (!seriously!) but you can have a go if you want. If you haven't got this game, what are you actually waiting for? GOTY 2007 10/10

content:
er 17, 2013
												Think Metro 2033 but more sandboxy and with more realistic gameplay.Or Operation Flashpoint but you are the Russians and it's fun. All that said, the first time I bought Stalker and loaded it up I only lasted a hour before it bailed out on me and crashed repeatedly everytime I tried playing it. A game that I can't play 0/10.About three years later I made a second attempt, this time with a new computer. I began running around waving a pistol around in a environment that looked like it was built by a map editor on a Sunday afternoon. It could have had a better start, but better starts nothing when I realized how much I enjoyed it while engaged in street-level fighting armed with a laser rifle while backed by some cheap knockoffs of the Brotherhoods of Steel from Fallout 3. All this in day long gaming sessions that would generally be considered 'unhealthy' by those who have successful social lives. But it's a testament for how addicitng and honest-to-god engaging this game was for me with its sense of realism, acute open-worldiness, and how I feel like I am treated like someone with brains if I want to win rather than the tiptoe-through-the-garden-markers-on-every-interactable that so many other games *cough Assassin's Creed cough* do. I really don't know why I'm constantly comparing Stalker to other games, but let it be said that Stalker did come out in 2003, before all of them, so let's put a big medal for originality then eh?8.5/10
